author: Slow Hand
content:
Man. I am loving the De-emphasis section on Tupe. It lets you squeeze so much saturation out of a signal without driving things too hard. 

First, you drive your signal to the point where the loudest part starts to break up, then you use the de-emphasis to subtract that frequency from the saturation circuit and then you push the gain up even harder until you're on the edge of breakup again. Wash, rinse, repeat. 

What you end up with is a signal that's evenly saturated across the entire frequency range instead of only having the loudest parts treated, because they're all hitting the saturation at roughly the same level. This thing is amazing. It's the sound that I've been searching for for soooo long.

author: Oli J
content: I’d say it’s a combination of things. Arrangement, balance and eq are two most obvious. I’m often looking for bright but not harsh. Other tools worth checking out are soothe, pro-mb (multi band compression to tame those highs) and I sometimes find tape simulation or drive can help. Saturn 2 is a great tool for this too. Feel free to send me a mix where you’re at and I can try and shed some light on a couple of things that might help.

author: BatMeckley
content:
This is easily the nicest and most knowledgeable forum for audio discussion I’ve ever seen. I’m taken aback daily on Gearspace and theGearPage how people with absolutely no real world experience wax poetic about the quality of this piece of gear over that piece, and how quickly every thread devolves into nothing useful. On this discord experts and beginners alike are constantly giving and receiving real knowledge that actually helps make records, rather than “which plugin gives the LUFS”. I’ve been at this music thing a long time and nearly every single day I learn something new and useful to apply to my next session. 

If someone really came onto this forum and found the heat of this particular kitchen too hot for them, I imagine life might continue to be hard for them. This is about as good as it gets, and if there’s a place giving out better info from better people I’d love to hear about it. What @oaklandmatt has curated is pretty special. It’s not a daycare, it’s a place to get better.

author: montrose recording
content: been thinking alot recently about sonic preference and our 'lanes'.  recently saw a great Q+A with a filmmakers crew post screening and their biggest advice to young filmmakers was to stick to what drives you individually and pursue that to the highest level you can.  since joining this discord, i've felt more internal pull to 'clean things up' and 'not over do shit' - but im feeling (enough of it to want to share) that perhaps my lane is the opposite.  im drawn to smeary, crazy sounding productions. over and over again i'll hear some clean record people rave about and totally feel bored and disinterested - and the opposite is true, i'll hear the most distorted, or digitally mangled productions and love it.  so - all that being said - i'm not trying to be the devil on the shoulder here - but perhaps a reminder to myself and anyone whos on the quest to stick to your gut and try and make the thing as good as it can possibly be to you.

author: BatMeckley
content: Tape over the needle. LISTEN. I’m not one of those people that barely is kissing it, but I’m also not trying to bury the needle constantly. Listen for when excitement and vibe turn in to take killing distortion. Then, back it off a hair. A general rule for setting all gear is turn all the knobs to extremes one by one. author: NoahNeedleman
content:
So there’s an old saying: if you wanna really know something, you gotta learn it, you gotta do it, then you gotta teach it. 

My friend who mentioned wanting to learn how to mix yesterday was amazed at how fast I was able to make his track sound big and loud and open all at the same time. “My mix sounded so small and congested. Yours sounds huge.”


Basically what I did, besides level & panning, was carve out a bunch of like 400 in all harmonic elements. All the tracks sounded good, but the density was all bunched up down in that range. 

As I was explaining it to him, I had a moment of clarity about headroom. Doesn’t matter if all frequencies are present for a big and tall mix, if all the headroom is getting eaten up by everything hitting the same frequencies, the collective volume of that is gonna make everything else feel quieter. 

I usually think of headroom in regard to low end and transients, but it’s true for every part of a mix.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
@BoozleBAM This is a GREAT question, and having read the whole convo twice I don't think it was really answered. Honestly I probably won't be able to answer it either, but here are some thoughts in no particular order

First the usual caveat, I'm not a mixer and I haven't mixed a record in a decade. But I did record and mix for 20 years before that and followed the whole arc from beginner not understanding compression, to pro finding my way and getting to own or use all of the baller dream hardware. All that to say I have a lot of empathy for where you are at with it. These are not definitive statements, just aspects to think about..

1) First something of a hot take that I don't see represented online. IMO compression often makes an individual instrument sound "worse". If you play and record something like drums well or acoustic guitar well, a compressed version will often sound *less real* and less vital. So why in the world would we do it???

- The first reason is that we mostly don't care about how individual instruments sound, we care about the whole song. Often a compressed sound will play nicer in an arrangement than something dynamic, real and recorded in a "documentarian" way

- The second reason is a trade off that isn't often spoken about. Compressed instruments often translate better into the wild. Take a beautiful, dynamic, real sounding, hifi & documentarian recording of say upright bass, drums and acoustic guitar. Listen in your studio in great monitors and it's a dream. Now go to Target and play it in mono on the overhead speaker on a busy saturday.....it just won't survive ... the song gets lost. Or drive with your window open, or cook dinner with the AC on etc etc.

author: cian riordan
content: This is a fun trick we discovered in the early days of Saturn. Eric came from tape and he was always cranking the high end on the record side going to tape to account for noise on mix down (easier to tame low end than it is to boost when you're mixing off of tape)... but there was a cool high end sheen that you'd get. So with Saturn, you just separate a high frequency band above what is really audible and just crank the gain on the warm tape setting. Obviously you can adjust to taste, but it's a great way to add a little air & excitement to some dull recordings.

author: cian riordan

author: Matt Huber
content:
Not sure how many folks are doing this, but figured I’d share in case it would help your mixing workflow. 

I have my sessions set up with busses that allow for me to be able to print my main, heated ref and all of my alt prints at once. 

When it’s time to print, I copy my mix buss to the alt print tracks and then bounce by highlighting the last 6 tracks, right click…”bounce”

Saves TONS of time

Been getting my verbs slotted quickly since figuring this one out.

author: bobby k
content:
Mind if I ramble? I'm working on what is probably the most challenging mix I've done this year. I've been at my first pass for close to 2 weeks, and have probably started it over 4 times. For context, it's a very dense country rock song with like 80-90 tracks, heavy heavy buss processing, many layers hitting exceptional stages of compression and saturation. The most challenging part is that, despite my philosophical differences from the producer's template, the rough mix really works. Anytime I try to strip it back, import my template, do my own thing, make the mix fit into my "mixing philosophy", it just falls apart. I've considered stemming it out with Bounce Factory through his template to then put the tracks into my template, but that would be a zero sum game I can already expect to lose. 

Ultimately I've had to shift my perspective of wondering "why am I here?" I'm learning that my role is not to run this song through some proprietary process I take pride in, but to simply just help them reach the finish line by trying to understand and continue within the process they've already deeply baked this song through. I've found that I can apply my perspective while setting my "process" aside, and explore what small tweaks or decisions I *can* make that get us the last couple % we might be missing. Any previous approach I've tried I already know would result in a 10+ revision nightmare trying to get back to the original magic of the rough.

And on the interpersonal front, I've decided against sharing any of this struggle with the artist. Maybe the mix that gets approved of the 4 that I've done is the one I spent 30 minutes on, but the many hours of me feeling like I'm "failing" on the other 3 passes were needed to understand that this track only needed 30 minutes of my time. Excuses don't get us to the finish line. 

What has been your experience in these situations?

author: Rollmottle
content: when you are really slamming something for level and you're trying to do so as transparently as possible, that's where oversampling really comes in handy. it's kind of remarkable what you can transparently get away with with a limiter when you oversample. in a production context, it all depends what you're going for...if you want grit, leave the oversampling off. just another tool in the toolbox.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
I’ve got thoughts here on this artisan vs technician topic. 

When writing songs, I find that inspiration can’t really be counted on to show up when you want it to. But not working when you don’t feel inspired leads to atrophied creative muscles, which is paradoxical, but true. It’s why the saying “the muse finds you working” is a thing. 

So what I found when choosing to write despite not being inspired, was that that’s the only time I could work on the *craft*. Inspiration is a slave driver. 

This held true over into the recording world for me as well. When I was trying to capture something in my head I was a slave to it, but when I’m trying to capture something in someone else’s head, I’m merely curious and experimental. And *that’s* when I learned the craft. Mixing, recording, producing, etc. 

The TL;DR of it all is I think being a service oriented technician is a major part of growing into your artistry. At least it was for me.

author: Matt Huber
content: Saturn 2, warm tape mode, single band. Pull LF back 1.8 to flatten and then trim in back -24 and output up 24. The drive knob then becomes a really gentle saturator. It can be very subtle and very nice for coloration and density.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
**VCA compressors** - examples would be the SSL bus or channel compressors, or the DBX160. These have less instrinsic tone or color from distortion etc but grab and shape envelopes in a very particular way that can be really useful. Punchy would be a decent overall descriptor
 
**Opto** LA-2A, CL-1B etc. These tend to have fast attacks and a release that starts fast and then slows down which can give them a lovely forgiving character on certain instruments. They often come with tube line amps and with that distortion from the tubes and transformer which can add body. They can add a kind of glow or richness to a sound, holding it in place in a gentle musical way

**FET** 1176, Spectrasonics 610, Compex, Distressor etc. These can have very fast attack, and a release that can be varied from very fast and explosive to slower. The FET itself causes quite a bit of distortion which gives them a spanky and very alive kind of character. They often have a "smaller sound" that focusses things, grabs attention and brings it to the front of a mix

**Vari-Mu** Fairchild, Manley Varimu, BG2, Magic Death Eye etc. These us a tube as the actual gain reduction element and tend to have a low and varying ratio, attack and releases that are musically linked, a gentle knee and often add tone and weight becuase of the low order harmonics they add. They can be a little "slow" and sludgy sometimes but when they are right they are really right

-

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Some thing I hear reasonably often in mixes from clients - using saturation to help low freq elements cut through on small speakers. But the distortion moves LF energy “up” and if the areas where the 2nd/3rd/4th harmonic will live is already full (say with synths, or low guitars) then things get cluttered fast

author: cian riordan
content: With bass, I'm usually compressing the bass and getting the DI pumping how I like, then bringing the level up in to the -4 to -6 dbFS or so. Then I'll make a mono, post fader send to a mono aux with sansamp. I'll send a healthy level then start by adding a little bit of drive, then playing with the buzz, punch, and crunch to fold in the distortion -- but thinking of it like an EQ. Using it to fill in the harmonic gaps that aren't cutting through when the drums and guitars are going. Very rarely touching the high/low eq on the right.

author: Slow Hand
content: Finally - and I think most interesting - I was able to approximate a saturation profile close to the *VT-7* using *Valhalla Delay*. Sooooo I guess go ahead and slap that bad boy onto your master bus, folks 😉 :

author: ALXCPH
content:
theres so many ways to interpret this question. so here's my take. Mixing to me at least, is all about bringing out the intent of the record to the best of your abilities. Fx. if you are mixing a Classical record, all you aim for is probably getting something as close to being in the room as possible, and therefore fidelity. If you are mixing some new urban underground cultural music, you want to respect the grittiness as that can sometimes be part of the sound and/or culture, and you never want to remove the inherent DNA of what makes that thing exciting(even tho it might be unconventional). So in the end, it's OUR job to make the decisions on when to be rough and when to be high fidelity. It's all about what you want out of the music. For most mainstream music(aka. radio oriented) i would personally get a bit of both. Get the mix sounding somewhat exciting as to pull in the listener, but also have certain aspects be high fidelity as to make it easy to listen to. FX, in a pop record, Vocal intelligibility is super important if you want people to sing along, where are in a techno track or hyperpop track you can have some grittier vocals, as they aren't as intended to be the in the car sing along song. They would be much more about the energy and feeling. 

IMO theres nothing more boring than a perfect mix, where every sound is perfectly inline and has no personality that makes it memorable. 

The creativity of a mix is just as, if not more important, than the technicals. Thats what those cyborgs called Mastering Engineers are for.

author: Slow Hand
content:
As Justin and Zack said, there's no wrong answer here. It's achievable both ways.

But since you're having trouble getting your verbs to pop out in the way you want, here are a few things that will get you there. Usually a combination of these things:

**1.** Turn up the verb - Simple, I know.
**2.** Make space for the verb - Mute or EQ competing elements.
**3.** Increase your pre-delay time to the range of 60ms - 150 ms. This "disconnects" your verb from the source and makes it stand out more. And this sometimes means you can turn it down and still have the clarity. 
**4.** Use an echo instead of a verb - This sometimes does the thing and takes up less space.
**5.** Use a slap echo instead of a verb - One and done. Gives you that room-y feel without taking up a lot of space.
**6.** EQ muddy/thick/harsh frequencies out of your verb, so that you can turn it up louder without overwhelming the mix.
**7.** Gently apply an effect (distortion, phaser, etc) that will make it contrast and catch the ear easier.

author: Jonathan Jetter
content: When I do end up w/ parallel something, it's almost always because the parallel comp is really mostly a parallel overdrive. A clean comp in parallel is very similar (not quite the same, but close) to lowering the ratio of a normal comp.

author: Eric Martin
content:
Just from the hour of watching JC mix yesterday I understand a little better how things get “loud” in his mixing. He uses peak limiters and clippers everywhere, so nothing has a chance of peaking out from where he placed it. That’s in effect trimming all the Attack of an instrument but not really messing with the decay sustain or release because with a peak limiter it’s acting so fast that you can use it to manipulate a sound without it drastically changing the other aspects of it ADSR in synth world works the same in all audio. A clipper does the manipulation for “saturation” to get the desired grit that we might have gotten in yesteryear from things like tubes tape and transformers.

I think that it’s likely a smart fast and easy way to get a result like JC is looking for where it’s loud and sounds open still. Because you can’t really hear the peak limiting like you can hear a compressor doing 4:1 compression. Also know JC has a 1k “handicap” as he calls it on his mix bus, pulling out a few db and he is using the spectral shaper from 1-6k to tame harshness on the mix bus. (Don’t do this just because he does) These are things he’s added because it helps him get to his desired result faster, and when you mix one or two songs a day everyday for years you’re going to develop “tricks” or “handicaps” or whatever you want to call them to help you get to your desired result.

Learn everything you can about mixing if that’s what you want to do, and use only the things you try that YOU like, not because someone else makes work you like, your mileage may vary

author: Slow Hand
content: Since you're trying to get more juice out of Pro-L2, I would give this guide a quick read. The biggest takeaway for me is that the Attack knob on Pro-L2 is counterintuitive and dialing the attack time all the way back to 10s will get you less distortion and a feeling of more attack and transient (while retaining the same limiting): https://www.jonathanjetter.com/blog/fabfilter-prol2-timeconstants

author: ALXCPH
content:
this is answer might not be the most exciting.

Actual Separation does not come from EQ, Compression and Saturation. These are just tool to help manipulate a sound into how you want it to sound. 

Separation comes from Arrangement. If you have a Piano and a Guitar playing full chords in the same octave, you'll never get good sounding separation, no matter how much you try and manipulate the sound.
Sounds are made from a fundamental and certain overtones/harmonics. If they overlap, then they overlap, even if you add a random eq boost on each sound some Freqs apart, because someone on youtube did that. (not that you can't do it, and it wont work)
But Instead of removing good sounding parts of a sound forcing them to fit together(whatever that even means at this point), arrange the parts so they naturally fit together with separation. This way you'll be able to act more, creatively and instinctively on how you want the sounds to sound while mixing, instead of fitting a triangle into a circle. As the good old saying says, it starts at the source, for the best results. 

Fx, in a typical jazz band, often a Bass will play roots on 1 & 3,  a piano will of then play the root and 5th an octave above that, and a guitar could play the 3rd and 7th, and together all the instruments make big full chords while also having their own space. this way there is now plenty of room for a singer or a Sax player to do its thing and not worry to much about cutting through a dense mix.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Man it goes both ways- sometimes if you’ve got problem frequencies or too much bottom a compressor will react to the wrong things, and depending on what you’re using to compress there may be problem frequencies imparted. I wouldn’t be afraid to eq both before and after compression/saturation. 

There’s no limit on the amount of plugins you can put on a vocal chain, so often I approach it with a lot of things doing a little bit at a time, just adding or subtracting things I’m looking for.

But if more freedoms is stressing you out, try this approach. 
Add a comp in the second slot
See what jumps out at you, and then decide if you need to eq what’s going into the comp, or just what’s coming out of it.
Subtractive eq 
De essing 
More compression/saturation
More subtractive eq/de essing 
Additive eq 
Any final touches (limiting, saturation, de essing, etc)
Fx 

Use as many plugs as you think you need to. 

Then go back and disable everything, adding them back one at a time to make sure everything you’ve done is helpful on a fresh listen. 

If you love everything you’ve done but need a little more on the chain, commit and start as if that’s your recorded vocal and go from there.

author: cian riordan
content: One doest really substitute for the other. Backblaze is a true set-and-forget backup system. Just dumps your shit to the cloud with no storage limits. Getting files is a bit of a pain… you don’t access them the same way as you do with Dropbox. You have to use the clunky web interface to prepare a download of files/directories you’ve selected. Then you get an email when the file is ready to download. Dropbox feels like a drive attached to your computer, hence how easy it is to use… and the expense. I use both — Dropbox more so for collaboration rather than backup,

author: peterlabberton
content:
I think Auto-Align 2 just totally saved my ass with an acoustic gtr/vocal recording/mix.

Was doing a little one-off tracking date with a big artist I'm trying to work with more and more, and I feel like I didn't do my best on the recording side. Could have and should have taken up a member here on a generous mic lending offer (you know who you are 🙏 ), but decided I could roll with my own gear. Acoustic gtr and vocal, tracked together—would have done the two figure 8 mics/use the nulls move with the borrowed mics, but I don't have two fig 8 mics right now. A drive across town would have gotten me the right tools for the job and made everything smooth and easy. Lesson learned: get the right shit no matter what!

Artist left in good spirits, job done, fine. But I was super bummed, I had wanted to blow them away. Had to step away for a few days, and then spent most of yesterday trying every trick in my book to get the phase of the vocal and gtr mic to be happy (it sounded fine so long as the artist wasn't singing loud—then it became phase city in a few loud passages as the gtr mic got more and more vocal). Time adjuster, playing with Little Labs IBP, EQ, whatever. Still mostly a huge bummer. But! Auto-Align 2 did some spectral phase shift magic that I don't think I would have been able to suss out on my own—holy shit, what a relief! Maybe I love our new AI overlords after all. (I think this plug-in claims AI magic... whatev, it's tight.)

author: Slow Hand
content:
I'm really enjoying the new *VCME Soft Clip* from Goodhertz, which comes free with their *VCME* limiter. They spun the clipping section off into it's own plugin and it feels great to overdrive it. Everything breaks up in a musical way, and the slew controls are good for voicing how the dynamics drive the distortion at the attack or tail of the sound.

Maybe the distortion algorithms aren't anything new, but they sound amazing and the entire tool is designed in a way that's musical, which I think is one Goodhertz's biggest strengths. They have a great intuition for voicing parameters and their curves in a way that is highly musical and hard to go wrong with. They feel like toys that bring joy and not like I have to crunch the physics in my mind to get results. https://goodhertz.com/vcme-soft-clip/

author: Rob Domos
content: I do something similar fairly often. If the musicality of the notes of an element aren’t coming through or things feel foggy rather than solid, often it’s because harmonics are competing with the fundamental for what pitch we perceive it as. author: Rollmottle
content: It smears/kneecaps transients in exchange for the small possibility that your master may distort on somebody's playback system somewhere. You could also turn down the limiter gain at which point that possibility of audible distortions in those playback systems diminishes, at which point, you can just turn it off anyways and keep your transients. For most modern music in most modern playback scenarios, none of that will matter and the trade off is not worth it.

author: Slow Hand
content:
To double-back on the topic of stacking, I've never had much luck with (nor cared to try) stacking dynamics and EQ's, but there's one category where I *love* stacking stuff: *distortion*.

This is probably no surprise to guitarists, but you can get some fantastic textures by layering two different saturators. Michael Beinhorn really got me thinking about it a while back and it's such a fun thing to explore.

I love taking two instances of *Decapitator* (each with a different setting) and driving the second stage really hard, but only driving the first stage a little bit. You can get some lovely harmonic "blooms" that are undeniably distorted but somehow very reactive and dynamic.

author: Jonathan Jetter
content:
A+ advice above. Few small things I'd add:

1. Don't be overly concerned by what you see on the screen. A certain style on a compressor that says "clean" may not actually be. It may have more harmonics than various other styles on the same plugin. Certain meters move faster than others, not all 10ms attack times will actually attack the same, certain GUIs that imply some sort of analog modeling may not actually do so, etc. Just listen and trust your ears.

2. If you can't hear certain aspects right away, that's fine too. You can't force it, don't rush it. Still just listen and trust your ears.

3. I liked compression less when my monitoring was lousy and not suitably dynamic, because everything sounded more compressed than it actually was.

author: cian riordan
content: @Zack Hames On second look, this comes off kind of jerk-ey and I didn't meant to just brush off your quest for saturation dominance! I guess what I meant to say is that through the dozens of interviews with Jon and Matt, it's clear that he's averse to using compressors and tends to use saturators more to do the job. While I fuckin' LOVE me some saturators, I honestly don't see the two as interchangeable... they're just two very different tools. One is leveling volume and the other is distorting a waveform to generate harmonics. I think saturators are a great next level tool for people who have wrapped their brains around compression.... but you really need some form of compression on an un-treated vocal. I feel in contemporary music, people are leaning too much on high-end saturation to get things to sound exciting and hyped. If I'm ever using saturators to distort things (which is often), I'm always trying to find some sort of un-distorted high end source to help the ears cling to clarity in the mix. Sometimes, things will distort in a way that will add this clarity -- or even manufacture it. But most of these multi-band saturators are just adding a layer of fuzz to the entire midrange up and the whole mix just ends up sounding hazy. IMO, a great example of modern hip-hop mixing is Mac Miller's Circles. The high end on that record sounds just as exciting as anything else, but it doesn't sound like everything got ran through a buzz saw (shoutout Greg Koller/Jon Brion). Just my 0.02.

author: ehutton21
content:
Late to the party but just wanted to add that I think time away from the mix can really help this process too. It’s not sexy but it’s ol’ reliable. 

In lieu of that though, I’ll try to bring something original to the party but it’s more arrangement based than sheer mix advice (but everything starts in the arrangement!)

Resolution of tension is what makes pop choruses satisfying, both harmonically and dynamically. In theory, this emphasizes what @Zack Hames and others said—good choruses shines because of contrast. Often times, if you have a build up to a chorus or a transition into it, I like to look at the “easy to undercook” elements like risers/rev reverbs, beat cuts, and harmonic layers/white noise to ensure there’s that layer of “ooo,” “aaa,” and “wow”. Good rev verbs/risers shouldn’t just be random white noise, I find a lot of success in tuning them and then automating the tuning so the pitch rises as well. Play with that. A great beat cut on the last count before a chorus is a killer idea. Try cutting the melodic elements and leaving the bass, maybe cutting everything—listen to some Neptunes era stuff for inspo, or just more Neptunes in general honestly for pop music references.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
- The classic example of compression is to use a fast release with something like a parallel drum buss. As the release lets go and brings up the room gain you get this urgent and explosive energy. When the room is good, and the compression timing is set right it can really make things sound bigger than real life. Remember we're trying to tell a story here, we can't jam the *actual* real power and size of stadium rock drums into that mono speaker at Target but listen to Paradise City and it tells the story pretty well ... our brain does an amazing job of filling in the rest

- The last example is using something like a good tube compressor on vocals. With a nice soft knee and lots of gain reduction we get bring up a bunch of low level and emotional detail, breathy whispery stuff at the end of lines etc that can really help a lyric connect. Often with something like a good tube compressor we get a healthy amount of harmonic distortion too along for the ride which adds weight to the vocal and draws the listeners attention

author: Matt Huber
content:
What Josh said has been super helpful for me. 

Also, an easy thing to forget is level matching. Most tape plugins by default making things a bit louder, so make sure to compensate for that. Oftentimes, after level matching, I feel that a lot of tape plugins can make things come across “smaller” or duller  due to the transient rounding and (sometimes) the saturation. 

But also, sometimes those things are THE vibe for the song.

author: bobby k
content:
sam and i were DM-ing separately about this too, but I'm copying a message I shared about why I like to trigger in samples from the same kit/session if anybody cares to chime in... 

*"many different answers to this based on what you're working on but i'll use today's mix on my end as an example. mixing the audio for a live in studio recording of an artist that is quite pop, but tours with a tight band that makes the music much more live. Wanting this to be a hybrid of the two sounds, not a live show and not a spotify release but somewhere in the middle, so I premixed the snare/kick/tom samples and triggered them in. My favorite element for this is that I can work with the overheads in addition to the close mics and sculpt those to fit each drum. For example, the toms I'm blasting the overhead with tape saturation that is giving them a nice airy attack. then when I trigger them in, I'm essentially getting that tone from the overheads without applying that processing to the entire overhead mix (which has loads of cymbals). If most of my snare tone was coming from just close mics, I wouldn't care as much about triggering it would just be more for a consistent sound. but since I can sculpt the overheads so distinctly for each drum, it's making a much bigger impact on the mix to use these samples. additionally, i'm triggering in the kick and snare from the original track, which are kind of pop/electronic sounding, and just blending them in enough to get the attitude of the studio version."*

author: Eric Martin
content:
The LUFS loudness algorithm filters the low end and the top end when calculating, it’s pretty complex math.

IMO I don’t think people are using these EQs so that a meter reads louder but rather that the music sounds better when it’s louder, the distortion artifacts of clipping start building up in that range and it’s hard to build a solid mix that slams and feels good when it’s gummed up in that range.

author: cian riordan
content: Well from experience, there are certain instruments that take better to additive high-mid saturation -- bass guitars, vocals, etc. Some others -- like certain brass instruments, violins, etc -- can get really harsh if you push those too far. I would start by going heavy handed on the most innocuous of the pile-up and see where that takes you. Saturation is a great way of doing this without making things pokey... but might be good to audition with an EQ first to see what zones you should focus in on. Once you have an idea of where you're going, then you can fire up Saturn 2 or Spectre or Neutron and go to work.

author: Jeremy Klein
content:
im a bit of an outlier in this regard, but i dont really like spectre for adding high end. Sounds too brittle to me, no matter the distortion type. 

My favorite use for it is adding warmth to sounds in the low mid and lows. I really like the tube mode for this. 

I also fine the higher up the frequency range you go, the more subtle you have to be with the db boosts. I rarely have found myself using anything higher than ~3db with it

Combination of multiple clippers on diff elements, automation of master volume, soft clipping to shave off peaks before the limiter.. If that’s not possible then I always think two things: could the arrangement be better? Does the song need to be this loud? That usually helps me to come to terms with where the disconnect is

author: cian riordan
content:
Couple of random thoughts:
1. If the synth is extremely subby, consider pushing in some midrange via EQ or saturation to help definite it in the mix. Sometimes these synth basses are swimming in sub and the more you turn them up, the more it eats up headroom while still not really being able to hear it.
2. Are you competing against other low end sources outside of the kick? If so, you’ll have to divide and conquer the frequency ranges and let each one live in a specific zone. For example, if you have a bass guitar, make sure that its voiced in the fundamental 200-400hz area and leave the sub handle things below the kick.
3. Utilizing the analyzer in Pro-Q3 can be helpful for finding conflicting frequencies. You can throw Pro-Q3 on say the synth bass and the kick track, then on the synth bass instance, pull up the kick as a secondary histogram in Pro-Q3 and you’ll have a nice visual representation of where the kick is trying to punch through. You can then use some creative cutting to carve room for the kick. Or vice-versa.
4. Sometimes when nothing is working with synth bass and I need to do something drastic, I’ll delay one side of it 30mz to widen it out and get it out of the center. This can fall apart in certain mono-situations, but will often clear way for more bass instruments and the kick drum if done right.

As always, all of this is dependent on everything. YMMV.

author: Jonathan Jetter
content:
Certain group processing is easy, e.g. an EQ on a group is mathematically identical to the same EQ on each individual track.

Certain processing (e.g. Autotune) has to be monophonic in order to work right

Certain processing (dynamics, distortion) is very situation-dependent. And the more complex the chain, the more situation-dependent it becomes. And the linear processing (e.g. the EQ, but also most reverbs) then becomes different depending on whether it's before or after the nonlinear stuff.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Maybe I'm alone here, but does anyone else dislike the sound of clippers? Especially on the master buss. I hear it all over contemporary records and just don't care for the aesthetic.

Maybe I'm doing it wrong, but it always results in things sounding mush-y or smeared. The only amount that I like is barely perceptible, at which point I find myself wondering why bother at all(?). Whenever I try put it on a mix I eventually A/B it later and find myself liking the un-clipped version.

The only reliable usage I've found is on percussion that's very transient and very noise-y. Like a hand clap. It helps me to get the absolute level down, while boosting the apparent loudness.

Don't get me wrong, I love distortion, but I'm not a fan of that particular flavor.

author: chrissorem
content: @Slow Hand I almost always eq all fx and almost always make a a new verb or delay for  every new instance.  I can’t really think of a reason why I’d share fx unless I want something to melt together.  The fx end  up routing to their prospective group, for example vocal verb would go to vocal group ect and can be processed together if needed. I would almost never insert a verb on an individual track unless I want to push track back more into the mix. Or if I want a verb throw that simultaneously  turns the track down as I turn the verb up.  This is also the primary reason I don’t like inserting fx on a individual track. If you turn the fx up you are also Turing the dry down and in most cases I’m not trying do that. Also tend to process my fx, sometimes compression or saturation and also sometimes send fx to other fx. Example a delay feeding a verb

author: cian riordan
content: I like using Tupe for this. Boost that area on the EQ section then drive the “tubes” a little bit. A nice not subtle, but not overcooked way of doing it. Plus you don’t get all the compression artifacts if your vocal is already sufficiently contained dynamically.

author: JustinLeu
content: One thing to note with the “mix” amount, it really is a “maximum depth” control. Depending on what you are trying to accomplish you can drive the input/threshold (the actual knob labeled Depth haha)  but use the mix % to only reduce a small amount. Or (I find this to be how I use it on instruments most often) leave the “mix” 100% but play with the release until I’m only having to do a small amount of reduction but it sounds completely natural. This way if there is a crazy resonant spike I want to tame it will do it, but I am not having to hit the other areas hard at all.

author: chrissorem
content: For me the hardest part of mixing is scheduling.  The beauty in a tracking session is, that you are done at the end of the day.  When I send  mixes out I have zero control over when they will listen and give notes and when the project will be finished.  I tend to match the artist urgency or what works for my schedule. If they respond immediately I try and match that, if they wait two weeks it shows that it’s not that urgent unless discussed otherwise.  And at that point I add it to my list and prioritize accordingly.  If they ask when I will I work on it, I give an estimation “going to start  on so on so date…..   I’ve driven to the studio to many late nights to bust  “urgent” notes out to find I don’t hear from them for another week.  If it’s a big project, they will most likely have a team involved with real deadlines and I’ll make sure to meet those and generally management will put pressure on the artist to listen and give notes.  With Serban and Manny type operations, they don’t deal with any of this. They have a team to deal with it and they continue to mix accordingly.

author: Slow Hand
content:
This is a good point about letting your ears be the final arbiter. Hearing is believing.

That said, I *am* curious about why this has ended up making your mix sound less smeared and more punchy. I don't doubt your observations. However it's the exact opposite of what is supposed to happen.

The whole point of oversampling is to reduce aliasing foldback distortion, which absolutely *will* smear your audio with unrelated audio information (It's gross). I don't see how oversampling would effect punchiness (however we choose to measure that), but aliasing artifacts absolutely *will* cloud your mix.

author: spectrummasters
content: Fwiw , I am sure some plug ins don’t report their latency to your daw correctly and you have to be v careful . I know event horizon clipper in logic would do this . I’ll also  occasionally close the daw completely and reopen the program if I sense there’s any slight delay compensation issues in my mind I’m forcing it to re do all the maths on re opening the project (🤷🏼‍♂️lol) , the other thing I’m careful of is building chains as I get into the mix and then start switching plugs in and out or dragging their orders around too much too late in the mix , I’m sure this is when the maths gets a bit hectic . That’s probably me jus being superstitious on the last one . Logic time delay compensation isn’t where I’d want it to be personally (even paralleling is a bit dicey sometimes ) . It’s by doing these things I’ve been able to pretty much dissolve the “change of pocket “ feel you’re on about and I know v well . Also , I learnt recently that apparently in logic when you bounce all the latencies are more tightly corrected and it comes back together as tight as it ever was , but I work hybrid so that’s no good to me . Anyway good luck . Delay compensation can be a real limiter on mix decisions imo

author: Slow Hand
content:
I think it's important to recognize which "game" you're trying to play. Some people are playing the status game. Some people play the money game. Some people play the hit-making game. Some people play the artist/creativity/exploration game. Some people are playing the "I want to live in the woods and be left alone" game.

A big factor in stepping outside of these hierarchies is in your mindset. If you can be clear about what your actual values are then you will have a far easier time finding happiness and being satisfied leaving the other pursuits unrealized.

Then you can move laterally and pursue goals that are unique to you and that's probably the best thing that a lot of us have to offer the world: our opinionated, passion-driven, deep-diving life's work.

I mean hell, Spinoza was cast out from his Jewish community for his heretical and unconventional ideas about the nature of God. Now his *Ethics* is a beloved and wholly unique philosophical proof that endures and (to my knowledge) doesn't quite compare to anything else that people are doing in the field, even after several hundred years. He set himself apart by doing exactly what he wanted to. Shame he had to be exiled, though. 😭

author: JustinLeu
content: A few things I've found helpful is setting up my mix sessions with many points of control--- VCAs for all groups and then more specific (*All Music* *All Drums* *Kick/Snare* *All Vox* etc...) then a master fader controlling how hard I hit the 2bus. Starting with the biggest section of the song helps as well. I can then automate the other sections up or down *including the master fader feeding the 2bus*  As far as clipping/limiting on sources/busses I find it good to shape the sounds how I want (more heavy lifting) then the busses/2bus end up just glueing it together with a lighter touch. I think the 2bus doing too much of the lifting is where it can start to fall apart.

author: spectrummasters
content: If its any help, fwiw , imo It’s absolutely all about your gain structure and groups, and it’s kind of counter intuitive , you don’t want to be slamming anything ...just very careful db clipped here, db limited there ....across your buses . I have 6 group buses: . Kicks , 808/Bass , Drums , Music, Vox , FX and only clip by 1-2 db at the mixbus . Nothing clips by design or accident anywhere else .....for rnb/hip hop build your mix the Alex tumay / mixed by Ali way , get that 808 up first, on its own ....as loud as you want it , then build everything around it afterwards. Filtering is your friend. Have nothing in the low end but your bass. Overall I’d absolutely suggest watching Jon castelli mixing t Shine (he uses clipping well in there ) and mixed by Ali mixing YG , his mix balance and grouping is CHOICE. I say  somewhere between these two is the perfect rnb/hip hop mix lol . PS. I wouldn’t  do any of that edm/clip to zero stuff, it doesn’t work for anything other than serum madness.

author: sukhuno
content:
Yeah dude - it has essentially all of the features of ValhallaDelay already built in... so how i do it is I find the right time pocket (1/4, 1/8, etc) and then set it up in a rack. Then i will mess w the EQ settings of the delay signal to give it the right freq content. I personally only use the ping pong and stereo modes (never really use the M/S). 

Then in the third tab i set up the ducking  and mess with the threshold and release settings to duck out of the way of the lead. I love the sound of the echo swelling up after the phrase is done so i'll usually start at -15 for theshold and ~100ms for release and experiment from there. that third tab also has noise, gate, and a wobble option to add some more character. Then just like the diffusion setting in valhalladelay - you can use the reverb and decay settings to add verb to the delay signal pre/on feedback/post in the chain to give it more softness/space. 

But the killer feature is then you can modulate these settings in the 2nd tab... then i add a little percentage change to one side of the ping pong delay ~1.3% so it's not completely locked in and just adjust settings from there. on the first page, you can also drive the input super hard to get a distorted sound and bring down the output level (like a preamp). It's super versatile and you can get big swelling verb echoes or overdrive space echo type sounds.

author: Rob Domos
content: This is also the biggest reason that analog synths have so much more solid of a lowend than any digital synth. It’s not the saturation giving you that solidity. It’s that hardware LPFs don’t have anywhere near the same amount of cascading delay differential. I.e. a software bass synth by default has a slight reverb that is phase canceling itself wellllllll into the passband (like all the way down iirc) just by the nature of it having a digital LPF bottlenecked at 44.1, where a moog filter has very little of that going on because the sample rate of the real world is infinite, or the speed of light, depending on how you look at it.

author: Dusk
content:
1) Goodhertz is known for its UI. I find Faraday to be intuitive in a way other limiters aren't for me. The ability to alter the saturation is great. The warmth slider that makes a sound feel warmer or cooler is super fun to me. It's not transparent, but the limiting is gentler, so I like it guiding a sound into its place. Its goal is to make the overall artifacts of limiting more pleasing
2) I find it faster, more versatile, and better for limiting than a Vari-Mu emulation. Not to mention the UI is way more helpful than what I'm used to with a plugin looking to remind us of a Fairchild or similar
3) Yes, it just doesn't brickwall, and it has a vibe
4) You don't Need Tupe if you have a saturator you already like, but I adore it. I was skeptical at first, but I demoed it on drums, and it changed my life. Always on drums and bass guitar for me. Again, Goodhertz's UI makes it more versatile than any other Tube and/or Tape emulator I've seen. It has a million options to tailor the saturation. The Opto Compressor and simple EQ are fast and versatile. It sounds good

author: Rob Domos
content:
There are a lot of things that you’d usually want to fix regardless of any considerations in the track. Ie. Crazy plosives, mouth smacks, jacket rustling, mic stand bumping, noise fades, etc. I’ll typically get these janitorial fixes done without much thought of the context, (with the exception that I know to leave in a little more lip smack if it’s an aggressive rhythmic track than I do if it’s a ballad).  Beyond that my main thought is that I don’t want to hear the microphone. ie. mechanical sounding capsule buzz is something I tend to attenuate. 

All of this happens without me being able to hear the instrumental context (though I wish I could. RX integration into a daw context would be a game changer for me). 

Ruairi will rebalance the harmonics in a vowel, and while I also do that some in a vocal prep context, it’s harder because the undulation of resonances in a full musical context sometimes feels exciting while in solo it sounds off-putting. Ruairi gets to have the whole song in his RX window where I’m often only hearing the vocal, so I have to be a little more careful to imagine context and hedge my bets Hippocratic oath style, lest it looses some life.

author: Maxim
content:
I think that might be a limiting factor on top of the artists' abilities (Pop Smoke already sounded dope before his setup got professional https://youtu.be/317TP4JOSSE). I've recorded not-so-great rappers through nice chains and mixing wasn't the answer to save a (lacking) source. It never gave you *that* feeling. But even if you are recording great rappers cheaper mics tend to lack body and rarely have "boostable" or pleasant top end as you said. So it's a bit complicated before you even get to "mixing". Felt that was important to mention so you're not too hard on yourself.

But assuming that the limiting factor really is just mixing there's a bunch of options. First things first: is your monitoring and listening environment decent? Or are you on headphones? This could make placing vocals even harder for you. 

Then do you have a process that starts with vocal cleanup to get rid of or reduce unappealing harshness or performance issues? Despite being simple, people tend to skip basic tools like clip-gain to even out a performance. This should usually also give you some leeway for strategic boosts. Maybe instead of EQ look at harmonics. Fresh Air by Slate is free. Gem Dopamine is nice. Spectre is great. All of these should give you that "sizzle" you might be missing.

Then to get the presence and even out the performance you could try some parallel compression with something like an 1176. Also, try out Multiband Compression with the Mcdsp 404 or C6 or whatever you have to control the performance throughout the song once you've got a vocal sound you like.

I also find mixing the 808 & drums together with the vocal the most useful when it comes to gain staging and getting the song to feel right.

Obviously, there's more that could be said but I find processes more helpful than tools. It's art at the end of the day. Attached what Serban's assistant sees as their/his "mixing process". Mix more and experiment with what you have. Get feedback from the artists.

author: Adam Thein
content:
If retracking is still an option maybe that's the ideal solution, but three things that come to mind to me to try if it's pretty extreme is pulling up the audio in RX and using the lasso tool to just track that sweep (it should be pretty visible and consistent if it's bad enough you are automating an EQ to duck the resonance) and just gain that down enough to be able to use other tools more effectively).  Another thing I'd try if you have it is soothe2 if you can get it to mostly work on that resonance without killing the tone (even maybe these both in combination) and then finally I'd try something like Saturn or Kclip in multiband and try and use a combination of dynamics and saturation within that band to tame it further.  If it's really bad maybe a combination of those 3, or just automating an EQ but that sounds grueling and time consuming if it's throughout the entire performance.  Maybe Surfer EQ could also accomplish this but I don't have that plug.  I also think there's a Surfer EQ type function in Nectar or Neutron?  Somebody that knows Izotope's stuff better than me can probably chime in.

My 2 cents and probably there are some better solutions out there but this is where I'd start personally!

author: mixedbywong_my
content:
Id assume it be a slightly slow attack in a context of a limiter instead of a compressor (longer attack time) 
You can if the limiter has a look ahead function built in. Taken from the fabfilter Pro L manual 
“Lookahead
The Lookahead knob sets the look-ahead time for the initial 'transient' stage. This allows the limiter to examine the incoming audio in advance and predict the amount of gain reduction needed to meet the requested output level. If the look-ahead time is very short, the limiter doesn't have much time to move to the desired level: this will generally have the effect of preserving transients better and increasing the apparent loudness, but at the expense of possible distortion. Longer look-ahead times are safer, but less loud, and transients might appear to get lost in the mix a little more.”

author: oaklandmatt
content:
the main thing for phase issues is not hard tuning double/ triples. if you tune things aggressively, they will be pulled so accurately in pitch that they will phase in the frequency range of the note being sung (the fundamental plus some harmonics). 

depending on the type of song, i will either tune doubles less aggressively, or sometimes detune the whole vocal a couple cents within auto tune. you have to LISTEN (of course) and play with the options to see how wide/ chorusy/ flangey you want it to be.

author: Rob Domos
content: The same thing can happen with someone who sings in such a way that they create a lot of these bullshit dense harmonics. The worst offenders usually have their larynx touching their hyoid bone when they sing and have a fuckload of muscular tensions that cause harmonics that resonate at the frequency of the tension of the muscle. Think of it like changing the tension point on a guitar string by placing your finger on a fret to change the pitch, but at arbitrary points set by how tense your muscles are, and each muscle in your neck and face is acting as a mini speaker driver pushing out these random ass harmonics rather than a nice harmonic structure built off of the fundamental. Wallah, this person has the performance equivalent of a cheap capsule

author: Eric Martin
content:
the key is not to balance the double tracking too closely, left louder than the right or something similar, go very dark and very different for a rhythm guitar think fuzz on one side overdrive on the other, that will make the phase relationship so different that it sounds crazy wide and huge and not anywhere close to the same.

And also don’t play the part EXACTLY the same, think about locking in rhythms but accenting them slightly different.

author: Zack Hames
content:
I almost never use multiband comp tbh. I use multiband saturation all the time with Saturn.

The general reason i use it is to brighten something without simply adding a high shelf, or to create a broader wider transient on a drum track. The distortion with splay out the sharp transient. So I’ll saturate high end on vocals or bass to get more openness without harsh high end boosts, I’ll use the same sort of settings on close mics on acoustic drums to get more attack and punch. 

This is an Oversimplification but Nothing is bad in excess if it sounds good.  There are no rules.

author: Deleted User
content:
1. Corrective EQ in the Upper midrange/high end, notching out all the harsh resonances, taming the pick transients if the bass is played with a pick. I love the way MAAT Santa Cruz does this ever so smoothly. 
2. I compress the bass with a compressor sidechained to a LPF(!), to get some low end body which is usually severely lacking. The LPF is set between 1000-2000 hz, attack 0-8 ms and release 200-400 ms depending on the tempo of the song/bass part. Reducing 3-5 dB on peaks. This gets me really far.
3. If the bass is a shortscale, I’ll use Goodhertz Tiltshift to move the low mids from around 200 hz to around 100 hz, out of the way of the guitars. 
4. Then I put an amp emulation on the channel. Whichever one floats your boat. Plugin Alliance B15, Guitar Rig, TSE BOD, whatever. I’ll be boosting low end and cutting high end here, or before with a separate instance of Tiltshift. 
5. If I want the bass to sound „rock“ and cut, I send it to a parallel distortion, which can be anything. I like TSE BOD, which is another sansamp copy which  has a lot of sub. My trick here is to add a clipper before the sansamp to really get extra gnarl. Logic‘s stock Bitcrusher works great, but I’m sure anything works.

author: Deleted User
content:
It’s also worth listening if it’s attack portion or the sustain that is getting buried. 

If there is not enough attack on the bass, you can sometimes trigger sample (percussive sample, sometimes a really short foley thing) that has the right presence area to have a little something that adds a punch to the bass. I often just copy one note that works into other parts that don’t cut through but this stuff only works sometimes. It doesn’t really work with busier bass parts

And sustain wise, compression can help when it’s done right or make it worse when it isn’t done right. Same with saturation. I think with sustain, there’s a lot of nuance in how you want the sustain to sit- performance is a huge part of this. Sometimes there’s too much bright stuff and it doesn’t allow the sustain to be audible, if you can tell something’s down there but you can’t really feel it or hear it that might be the issue. I noticed when there’s too much or wrong compression on other upper elements, it becomes an issue. 

Also dup the track and start new and see where you can take it, sometimes there’s too much going on and hard to track what’s causing what.

author: ALXCPH
content:
20% is a metric ton of saturation imo. 

Soft Clip Classic

This is the default algorithm, and it’s the same one, which was used in the previous version.

Soft Clip Pro

This new algorithm has a slightly different characteristic. It compresses an adjustable dynamic range by half. A line in the function plot shows from which level the saturation begins. The dynamic integrity below this threshold stays intact.

25% - compresses the last 6 dB into 3 dB, and adds 3 dB
50% - compresses the last 12 dB into 6 dB, and adds 6 dB
75% - compresses the last 18 dB into 9 dB, and adds 9 dB
100% - compresses the last 24 dB into 12 dB, and adds 12 dB

content:
Sometimes Avid Lo-Fi’s saturation can help voice cymbals a little lower (by dulling/darkening).

Whatever approach you take, listen with all the drum mics in (don’t solo), as any processing will affect how the mics on a multimic’d kit interact with each other. 

Lo-Fi Saturation adds gain, and for some wild reason there’s no Output Trim on Lo-Fi, so you’ll have to compensate (or not) for that too.

author: Joshua Riley
content:
I’ve been using HitSend and honestly so many more pros need to hear about it! It’s got file management, mix notes, mix versions, invoicing and payment all built into one platform. I setup a project with the name and everything, setup the invoice and can choice whether I want a deposit or not, then create a playlist and add the mixes to that, Artist can add notes etc, you can go through multiple versions and then once it’s done, you add the files to the deliverables folder, they can click approve which will take them to a payment gateway to settle the invoice and straight after that, they download the deliverables package
There’s a few deeper tools as well such as password locking, who has access to what, if you’re just sharing a link you can choose which link has the ability to comment and approve, you can bring on project members as well so that they can manage the project and files and a few automation integrations as well as email notifications for everything. Also has google drive and Dropbox Integration

author: Adam Thein
content: I like to reach for brighter verbs in this kind of scenario - something with some texture like a spring or a plate or a digital verb with some texture.  Start there, mess with the width of it first.  Generally think if it more as a synth pad layer.  Emphasizing 2-5k if it really needs to cut with spectre or Saturn or a brighter saturation.  Using a delay in combination so that the decay envelope has some movement so my ear latches onto it more.  Panning, modulation, tremolo, etc, subtle ways to grab attention even at low level.  And good old volume automation.  Printing the verb can help give you some visual feedback for how it’s decaying.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
A producer bud of mine popped round a while back and blew my mind with what he managed to get out of a snare bottom with Saturn. 

Obviously different in every case but splitting the band at around 300-400Hz and smashing the the lower band in Old Tape mode pulled up a crazy amount of depth and character. Sort of thing that could help define a cool kit sound in the absence of other mics. Often lots of usable smash stuff in rack tom mic in desperate times (as it sounds like you know!)

Also side story, I was at Battery one day and one of Flood’s old engineers was being put through the ringer. He’d mixed a song for Flood 3 times already, and each time he’d send a version, Flood would be like “that’s great. Okay now take out everything but the hihat mic” and he’d have to rebuild a new mix based on that. Supremely fatiguing for poor John, but he came up with all sorts of really cool sonics to make the track work within the confines of those limitations.

author: Adam Thein
content: My intuition on this is that transient shapers will boost a larger length of “transient” than what the actual transient part of the sound is - so maybe if the snare transient is only 10ms of the recorded snare sound, the transient shaper is boosting the first 20ms of the sound and then you are clipping after, essentially lengthening the “transient” of the sound without increasing the peak level and simultaneously adding harmonics on that lengthened transient

author: Adam Thein
content:
Hey great question!  Even with “include return and master effects” checked in the export settings in Live, your tracks won’t 1:1 with dynamics processing or non linear processing (saturation) without using external side-chain routing.

I’d have a discussion with your mixer about if they’d like you to remove your mix bus or if they’d like it baked into each track/stem you are printing.  If it’s the latter, you can create sidechain source tracks to feed plugins that allow for an external sidechain input to keep it closer to 1:1 (still likely not fully accurate with the nonlinearities in some analog modeled plugins).

This is a pretty tough thing to type out but if we can find a few minutes today where our time overlaps I’m down to hop on a VC and show my workaround for this situation in Ableton.

author: JakeTB
content:
Here’s the long-winded human version. We’re still on this learning journey so happy for any pushback or insight

For the most part, our group felt the tradeoffs of very subtle multiband often outweigh the benefits, since just putting those crossovers in the signal makes a bigger difference than, say, a dB of control.

We felt more liberal use of multiband can add an aggression and excitement that is very familiar and unique, and prefer treating it as a sweetener or energizer over the whole mix more than trying to control problem areas that could be addressed on tracks.

In the signal chain, its position can drastically effect how other tools behave. Up front, it can help a bus compressor or saturation device behave more predictably, but may mush things too much. Near the end, it allows those devices to play a more colorful role but may cause weird behavior when using fast, “transparent” limiters afterward. I like it first right now, most of our group like it near the end.

The hallmark signs of overuse for us were mixes that sound overly strident or when a vocal becomes inconsistent tonally from section to section as density changes.

Tools-wise, the group unanimously preferred minimum phase tools over linear phase or dynamic phase. OTT is a starting point, ear training to recognize that color. Once you hear it at 15-20%, you won’t be able to unhear it on many pop records. After ingraining that color, ML4000 and C4 both have their own flavors that can do a thing while offering tweakability when needed.

author: Mike Tierney
content: Damn we out here talkin about intonation systems? A lot of my bread and butter is contemporary classical/microtonal/experimental music and I'm in this world as both an engineer and often as a producer keeping track of how folks relate to the score and each other, take maps, etc. I tend to agree with some of the above that trying to chase down inharmonic relationships with EQ can make things worse, but I appreciate @LAPhill posting about bassoon/flute overtone series. @spectrummasters original question was about understanding the low mids and how they relate to EQing depending on the key; I think for me the way that understanding overtone series, tuning systems, and musical interactions in acoustic/orchestral instruments can relate to pop or rock mixing is like... Sometimes when I hear clashes between instruments playing thirds or clashes in the harmonic series and I'm trying to clear space in the mids/low mids, I do think about what instruments want to be occupying that space. So perhaps in the bassoon/flute example, I'd want the flute's fundamental to be stronger than the bassoon's first harmonic at C5, and that might look like EQing down the bassoon in the ranges of the flute's fundamentals, or in a rock mix looking at the bass's harmonics compared to where the lower range of the guitars are living. Obv instruments are moving and changing notes so none of this is surgical so much as the keys of the songs or the instruments' ranges might inform some general decisions about where to make space rather than just "cut 300 on the bass" or whatev

author: Sam Segarra
content:
"How Equal Temperament Ruined Harmony" is a nice little digestable book on the topic. 

If anyone really wants to go deep and "get it", Mathieu's "Harmonic Experience" has the best approach I've encountered. He really does a good job explaining how each note in a scale is created, by outlining the specific harmonic relationship to the fundamental. I only formed a picture of the natural harmonic relationship of each note in my head after reading that one! It's funny to me that music theory doesn't start by teaching us where all the notes in a scale come from.

author: Slow Hand

I like the concept, but I wouldn't ever do it on the master buss because it constricts absolutely everything - not to mention potentially introducing phase-y distortions across the entire mix.

If I'm going to narrow that frequency range I'd do it only on the elements that are calling out to be narrowed in that range. Usually with EQ to darken the panned elements. My master buss ends up being *very* minimal and open to keep me from tying my hands at the end stage.

Then again, I'm also not Luca or Frank. If it works for *them*, cool!

author: onanisland
content:
yeah ive had it since it came out, same with soothe1 and all similar tools, @Joel "Roomie" Berghult was right. I tend to buy plugins to save time when projects come in. 

In the order I'd range these kind of tools mentioned here:

1. soothe
2. speccraft
3. reso and all others

If you have soothe, you're good imo. 

I liked this one (speccraft) because it gave me more control when I needed to chase a more targeted frequency without affecting the rest (i.e vocals, bass gtr, etc), stuff like that, but I use these kind of tools sparingly. cymbals, egtrs cabs, things like that, almost never on the mixbus because IMHO (don't shoot me), soothe-like tools, affect too much of the signal - suppressing resonances/frequencies "killing the depth" because of the pushing down of reverbs, delays, etc. That is not to say I never use it, there are times for everything, and every tool has its place but yeah. There are people who use it that way and still get GREAT results.
As much as I want to simplify my workflow, 90% of the job is audio janitorial, I go back to simple eq, compression, fader...

I saw another comment asking about Spiff > I don't know if anybody wanted my input on that but nevertheless - I like it sometimes on drums after tape-sims where it kills too much of the transients if I need to drive it more for *reasons* but the sound is lovely (i.e country), bit of spiff after and get best of borth worlds.

author: ALXCPH

This is over simplified but.
If you want “loud 808s” it’s all about levelling everything around it. Clipping your drums for a “loud” impact but low peak level.
Thin out your instruments/loops to make it seem like the bass is bigger than it is when it comes in. Because a bunch of the low mids will come from the 808. 
Saturation and clipping is your friend here.

author: Eric Martin
content:
transformers add harmonics, you could call that “smearing” because it spreads the audible frequencies out across multiple octaves.

Try putting a sustain 808 into a Neve preamp, you’ll hear the distortion that the Neve is adding to everything it’s used on, most of the time you can’t “hear” it but it’s happening.

Consider this, when a record was recorded to tape in the past, it hit the console then the tape, then when it was mixed, the tape went out and hit that same console again, further adding more harmonics.

JC is accomplish that sound through clippers, peak limiters, and transient designers, while allowing the low frequencies to get through which tape wouldn’t allow, best of both worlds

author: Rollmottle
content:
The loudness war is by no means over and never will be lol. Fucking myth. To get mega-loudness, you definitely need to stack limiters. Couple strategies to get you there:
- Make sure your De-essing is dialed in. That should soften some of the peaks that will end up gnarly once munched through multiple limiter stages.
- I've found I can get there much easier by driving a lot of density in the analog stage.
- Parallel processing can give you extra density and perceived loudness
- De-ess again if you have to
- One chain I've found great success in is: StandardClip after the analog stage into the Weiss Maximizer then into the ProL2. That has gotten me very clean and very fucking loud masters, but that is post an analog stage that is built for high headroom to drive serious level in the analog domain.

author: ehutton21
content:
Not Matt but as someone who works with hyper pop and “messier” genres, it’s about the fundamental stuff + being very humble as a mixer. 

By fundamentals I mean that a lot of this is about communication with the artist and figuring out what’s essential to them, or else how can you gain stage the good stuff? You gotta A/B the roughs and your refs a lot and make moves that are more decisive than super nitpicky too (be as detailed as necessary but be conscious that you don’t have to make this sound pop pretty). I remember I sent a mix to have @Rollmottle check out a couple months that wasn’t hyper-pop but I needed to go back and add in the grit of the bass actually pumping my final limiter cause it gave the mix life.

author: ehutton21
content: I find being deliberately messy is about knowing how to the basics very well and understanding your tools real well and understanding your process in context of the end product, rather than just chasing the end product. In pop music, you can kinda get away with over mixing something because you want things to sound super clean, and that leads you to overprocess.  Messy is about having the 808 nearly clipping the master rather than lowering it and trying to replicate that in other ways.

author: Adam Thein
content:
I've got it, just used it today actually - 

Pros, I think it sounds good, the metering is really unique and useful similar to their Smart Comp 2 which gives you a bit of reliable prediction as to how your moves are going to effect your RMS/Integrated LUFS.  Handy tools for starting points if you need them.  Some handy spectral tools to quickly change the color of the limiting that you may or may not find useful.

Cons - eats a ton of CPU, so much so that I tend not to use it even though I do prefer the sound for some things.  The automatic suggestion AI tool thing never does it for me, it almost always sets the attack around 100ms and auto release for me no matter what preset I'm using but maybe I am not diving deep enough into it.

Is it worth it?  Probably not if you have another limiter you trust.  I still reach for a clipper/Pro L2 combo the majority of the time personally.

author: sukhuno
content: Doesn’t this just mean you’re exporting the 32bit wav that has no clipping on it? Ie. you’re keeping the headroom you would have otherwise chopped off with a clipper or reduced with the limiter. The only problem I see with this is that you don’t know how other consumer dacs are going to respond to a signal that goes above and stays over 0db. It’s probably just going to clip anyways cause it won’t be able to handle the level. Honestly I would recommend trying an experiment with a limited, clipped, and just gain driven version and listen to them everywhere you can (Bluetooth speaker, phone speakers, AirPods, car) and see if it distorts over 0 - and then make your decision from there. It’s a different loudness game in electronic festival music for sure so they may not even mind the distortion but most mainstream leaning tracks won’t benefit from it

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Short version - clippers almost all have varying knees, and oversampling of some kind. Real useful null tests are not easy construct. Also some understanding of floating point vs fixed is useful

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Analog signals are always trying to see above noise at the bottom and below distortion at the top of the their range. When you have individual signals you want to optimize in that regard, and in a good old school console design the noise floor was always set by the mic pre.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: But the only distinction that matters in this case float/fixed and no one is accepting or serving float files so clipping of the kind in the video has to be “encoded” before releasing

author: sethearnest
content:
I’ve cleaned up that sort of clipping with the De-Clip module in RX. You can mess mess around with the slider to find where it feels best. 

How well it works seems to depend on how the source was clipped. Eg sometimes it’ll reconstruct the waveform all the way to not clipped; other times it won’t be able to get rid of the clipping. 

This is all presuming the clipping isn’t a creative decision.

author: Deleted User
content: Here’s the signal diagram from the manual. I can tell you what I do. I’m mixing through it the entire time. I’m always in soft clip classic. I start with the soft clip saturator slider at 25% (this controls knee shape and saturation level which will add gain). The clip slider is your threshold for where you want the clipping to occur however with the soft saturator knob above 0% there’s a knee to it. The output is post clipping and ignore the ceiling since you’ll likely be using a limiter following this.

author: Jonathan Jetter
content: If you match the output level, boosts are cuts and cuts are boosts, and it becomes a question of workflow. If there's dynamic or harmonic processing downstream, then it's about pushing harder into the processing vs. pushing less hard, and that's of course a choice to make. Some EQs (e.g. API) perhaps lend themselves to additive work because the proportional Q is super wide at +-2dB and sometimes people think of subtractive EQ as a tool for more narrow resonance notching, and it's a bit unfamiliar to have -2dB with a Q of 0.5 or whatever.

author: Adam Thein
content:
I've been here before a few times where the producer had a Soundshifter tuning up everything a weird amount (like 28 cents or something not even a semitone).  Generally I prefer the sound of shifting things separately - and at least on my system Soundshifter almost always has unpredictable and inconsistent stereo imaging artifacts so I usually prefer using other tools for as many tracks as I can do.  Most of the time since I'm working in Ableton I'll use the pitch shifting modes there (Beat warp on drums for example, tones or complex on individual harmonic instruments).

Play around with different shifting algorithms to get the results you want.  Be warned though that Soundshifter definitely has its own character/tone so if the producer/artist are really used to that sound they may wonder what happened if it goes away.  At the very least I'd try and warp your drums and vocals separately from the main instrumental if it were me!

author: cian riordan
content: Limiting, clipping, any sort of containment is useful at this stage. That way a big downbeat on the drums won't pull down the vocals, and vice versa. Also helps you tailor any sort of 'sweetening' type things for the program material -- ie, all of the electric guitars could use a little low mid boost and a little air up top.... but if you do that on the master, you fuck everything up. Just sort of a different way of thinking about staging your elements into the final mix bus. I find that with this method, the actual mix bus does less work and you get alot of the impact & loudness without many of the downsides.

author: Deleted User
content: Hey everyone, so a couple months ago I went to a workshop with one of the guys who worked on the loudness standard team for the european broadcast union and it was really interesting how he thinks about all that and how it translates to his mixing workflow in particular. So for those of you who don’t know in broadcast you have to hit a loudness of -23 LUFS +-1dBTP throughout the program. This is especially tricky with live program as you can imagine. But having this fixed loudness target also has a major advantage, it’s that you can have a fixed volume setting on your monitoring and with time you kinda know how loud you’re mixing compared to if you’re mixing for peak loudness, where you’ll always land on different loudness depending on the program. This was the first time I really understood the advantage of that way of working, because with time you’ll be so tuned to the loudness target you’ll be able to really intuit every move. And since -23 gives you boatloads of headroom you can really push things during mixing and then still get the density through clipping/limiting after that. It kinda ties in with what @Nomograph Mastering  was saying about fixed monitoring level. What do you guys think about that?

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Warmth

Alters the frequency-dependant characteristics of the limiter’s detector circuit.

A big part of Faraday Limiter’s thick, punchy sound is its frequency-dependent gain reduction. Low and high frequency sounds hit the limiter differently, and — depending on the Warmth setting — will exhibit different attack/release characteristics. High values, such as 100%, generally sound thicker and punchier, while low values, like -100%, have a quick, bright limiter sound.

For example, you can often use the warmth control to emphasize different aspects of a snare drum: more Warmth gives more thud & low end; less Warmth gives more stick & snare presence.

The Warmth control is not EQ, and will not change the frequency response of the plugin.
