Help your clients (artist/label) to make a call about where to land on that continuum, give them the info they need

Try a mix with a little less bus fireworks? Or try to figure out what aspect of the fireworks is troubling Mr Steel E Dan over at the station? (Clipping? S channel stuff?)

author: cian riordan
content: Best practice is: 1) Saturn 2 Preset -> 2) Q-Clone Preset -> 3) Some form of +10dB gain. My chain drops everything by 10dB for headroom so I make it up either Pro-L2 or GoldClip after. It's not really limiting or clipping, just bringing things back up to unity from what got sent out.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
This is good to know. The way I approached it was to build the mix with loads of headroom, then when it was all sitting roughly where it wanted to be, I’d alt+drag the input/output of Saturn to wherever it sounded good. It was usually followed by The Glue or another compressor (not always). When I first started using it I was thinking about where the harmonic stages would happen in a (Un)fairchild. I guess probably pre and post compression? There’s probably arguments to compress pre saturation, but I auditioned compression before and after Saturn and preferred it post on that occasion, so that’s how it stayed in the template.

The Pro-Q curve hedged against a tendency I had/have to mix too smiley, and all in all it seemed to make things sound more gooder so the duo lived on in my template… until it didn’t.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I find it's rarely necessary to compress a synthesizer if you're the one programming it. You already have control over the attack/sustain ratio on the instrument using the ADSR controls. And you can balance the harmonics through your choice of filtering or oscillators. Synthesizers rarely have low-level information to be revealed that can't simply be turned up at the source.

Of course, you might want the distortion artifacts from compression, but I'd probably use a saturator module.

That said, if you're a mixer who has received an audio bounce of a synth, then... sure! Compression would be good for balancing poke-y stuff, controlling boomy low-end, or there could be some room tone from a re-amp signal, or some attack that needs to be accentuated. So compress away!

author: LAPhill
content: I wouldn't think of it that way, unless the partials are really, really prominent. The first few harmonics can layer up to make a pronounced 5th or octave that's stronger than the sum of its parts, which can have unintended consequences. Like the 5th an octave higher on a power chord interacting with something on a bass note an octave lower. Sounds great until you have, say, a third instead of an octave between the guitar and bass. Suddenly your overtones are interacting in non-musical ways that usually create an unpleasant and out of tune smearing right where you want musical harmony to speak clearly. Again, all of this can be used with intention.

oversampling can have an impact in the sound when you're using a nonlinear process (distortion etc) because it shifts the aliasing out of the audible band, I pretty much never have a use for oversampling something like an EQ, and hardly ever for gentle compression
but the advice here is to choose based on the context, rather than "always oversample to 32x or else because reasons!"

sometimes that aliasing distortion or whatever other stuff is just what that sound needs

try doing some really really crazy settings with unfairchild and then toggling through the oversampling and see if that does anything, if you don't notice a difference you just saved some CPU power

author: Zack Hames
content:
Bands get all in a tizzy about spending $3000-10,000 on a full length. Money is not a given and everyone’s broke. But the reality is things cost money. 

If a band is super serious, or wants to take it seriously, think about what that looks like. 

You could get a talented engineer in a smaller scene to do a full length for $3000-5000, mixed and recorded. I don’t know of anyone in Kansas City that wouldn’t be happy with that do an album. If you have four members, could you not come up with $750/person? how much has everyone spent on their rigs? 

Obviously your band might be using inherited gear, maybe everyone’s completely broke, maybe everyone is using the absolute cheapest gear possible. I don’t know any details. But again, being realistic about all this, how serious do you want to take it, what are your sonic goals, etc.

Black keys recorded their own records on budget tape machines with few microphones, but their songs rocked and they were actively playing out and touring. 

Anyway, it’s no one size fits all. Just my ramblings. Would love to know more details, because it’s a super exciting part of life to be in a band and making a record

author: JustinLeu
content:
Keep it as simple as you can = )

Try doing the para processing from 1 send off of the main vocal and then blending the "dry" signal (original) with the wet signal at a vocal bus...

Para sends to try:
1. CLA76 or VU-comp or similar 1176 slamming away 
2. Distortion....so many options but you can try **Decapitator **(there are some great presets for gritty vocals....then just run them 100% wet since it is a send)  or the protools sans-amp

So routing will be:

Original vocal (dialed to roughly fit the track) with a SEND TO:
Para 1 (heavy comp)
Para 2 (disortion)
Bus all those tracks to:
Vocal bus...and on this treat the group as you need (comp,eq,limit,de-ess etc)

author: Slow Hand
content:
Ok. Trying this out.  I'm not gonna be as thorough this time, because that's a lot of variables to document with photos. So I'll give you my general observations and y'all can take me at my word.

I dropped the input signal to -20dB and then played around with boosting at 100Hz (where my test tone is) to see if the harmonics were different for different EQ band types. I tried a *bell*, a *low shelf*, and a *tilt shelf* to boost.

I was able to boost it +16dB in both *subtle* and *warm* mode before I got any of that harmonic breakup that we started to see in my previous tests as we got approached -0.03 dB. It appears that distortion on *subtle* mode (once again) doesn't kick in at all until the output signal gets within -4dB of 0dB on the output meter. The *amount* I boosted did not matter. The distortion only came when the signal crept close to 0 on the output meter.

All three band types appeared to behave the same when it came to harmonic bloom.
### tl;dr:
I did not detect any difference in behavior with different EQ band types. So they appear to behave the same. It's looking like the breakup doesn't kick in until the output level of the signal is within -4dB of 0dB on the output meter. *Then* they start to break up.

The only exception is the 1st order harmonic at -22dB that appears as soon as you enable *warm* mode. That's always present, no matter how hard you're driving it.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I tried that. I did see a *little* bit of variation, but it was subtle. Here are the two big observations:
### Subtle and Warm Mode
@ -0.03 input level, the harmonic bloom diminishes in amplitude as I sweep my test tone from 30 Hz (complex bloom) up to 4 kHz (totally gone). So it seems that the transfer curve is biased to break up in the low end sooner and you have to drive it *way* harder to get bloom after 2kHz.
### Warm Mode only
The 1st order harmonic seems to gradually drop 6dB in amplitude as I sweep my test tone from 30 Hz up to 1.8 kHz. It's still present after that, but it stops dropping in amplitude.

author: Eric Martin
content:
you’ll get no argument from me on the affect it has on the audio, 1-2db on a limiter or clipper can be barely audible while 1-2db on a traditional “compressor” might change the sound dramatically in a negative way.

Rounding transients is the goal IMO, keeping the impact while reducing the variance like tape, IMO Clippers can sound like the positive affects of tape without the negative

author: Deleted User
content: Loudness question: I’ve been struggling with drum samples and bass/808s specifically. A lot of these sounds come in so dense and compressed, they sound good in level close to 0dbfs but they don’t have the knock and energy they had when they are turned down to create headroom. Especially when it’s playing with other instruments that are more dynamic. A lot of times they even sound smaller and thinner too. So I’ve attempted using samples that have taller peaks but at the end of the day I end up doing similar treatments (distortion, clipping) to get the level of density and aggression. Which also leads to another question about transient treatments. I’ve watched tutorials on this topic and some people used clipper to have the limiter work less, and the others work slightly differently by preserving the peak and using parallel to create density. I tried both ways, but still left me with the issue of not being able to crank it louder without messing things up. With the dense drum samples, the rest of the mix would start choking every time the drums hit. Generally I find it so much easier to get things to compelling loudness when there’s no drum instrument (I find percussive elements with higher pitches easier to fit in the mix). How can I work around this?

author: Josh
content: I have no clue what your skill/gear level is, but are you sure you can hear everything properly? I had the same issue until I swapped monitors and actually heard what was happening to my 808s and drums. I do a lot of saturation (shout out to Nani) and use ozone’s low end refocus to get the 808 to sit a bit higher so it’s not all muddy.

author: Eric Martin
content: try this next time, when you get that 808/drum sample that sounds good at 0dbFS, turn it down to where you think it needs to be, then turn everything else down also, and turn the speakers up until the loudness of the 808 sounds the same as it did at 0, now start to pull all the other elements into the the mix and balance around that 808 without adding compression clipping or any other effects

author: Deleted User
content: To me personally, throws are more about what effects are followed after. My favorite post delay/reverb effects Unfiltered Audio Byome. For workflow, this is 10/10. It’s a modular multi effect plugin, and making a few different presets on it allows me to quickly switch around between different colors and modulation. It has random parameter set feature and can unexpectedly bring in interesting sounds quickly too. Other than that, I also like Soundtoys stuff for phaser and tremolos, ubermod for chorusing and other phase effects on the delays. For reverb, Dverb is actually pretty cool especially when it’s mixed in with delays. I like Valhalla vintage verb and eventide ultraverb as well. And for post verb or delay saturation, decapitator and spectre. Saturn if I wanna use the dynamics control on it. I also like messing with the polarity, sometimes flipping it can get the presence of the tail heard better without obscuring the dry sound as much.

author: seb
content:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DWbFq2qiHGY

Let's talk clipping. Is there anyone here that works on modern r&b/trap records and uses clipping to achieve that FL Studio sound? Jon mentions it here, Jaycen mentions it elsewhere.

I actually come from producing on FL so I'm quite familiar with the clipper there and the sound that it gives off. Most people use it on their master channel so when they bounce their stems, it's my understanding that they lose whatever sound they were getting from master processing (which sucks since it'd be nice to retain that stuff. Side note, any thoughts here)? 

I've used Ozone 9's limiter as a clipper on a drum buss while paralleling with soundtoys little radiator for that "FL" sound (as per Jaycen). It does sound nice, although I wouldn't say it quite matches the FL clipper. Jon mentions the tracks clipper -

Curious to hear anyone elses thoughts.

author: Zack Hames
content:
I think it’s tough to mimic those old classic records authentically unless you make them the old classic way. Consoles, tape machines, microphones of the era, hardware effects, instruments and techniques of the era. All those small variables add up to make it sound authentic. 

If someone knows how to circumvent that I’d love to know. I think the present/future is truly blending the classic sounds with modern (and probably always been).

author: Zack Hames
content:
For example, using drum machine samples from those eras could help get you there. But it’s still too clean because you’re not using them hardware into a bunch of transformers and a tape machine. 

On the flip side, a vintage pre and mic or a Yamaha dx7 gets me there VERY quickly and does so much of the work for me of getting real classic sounds.

author: Zack Hames

author: cy (sigh)
content:
0.1 is a percentage as far as i know. The actual amount of saturation deoends both on that the mix knob and the og sources inherent Harmonics that get excited. 

That same amount ona heavy bass won't saturate the same as ona soft flute for example (also depends on the freq  range)

That said I know a lot of mixers that swear by the warm mode on the exciter for even Harmonics And they are very subtle w it.

The eq idk. I'll never really used it but similarly I know a lot of mixers that swear by it. If there's really that much of a difference it's either 1. That's how it is on the eq that it's trying to emulate- it's a vintage style eq, I don't think it's meant to be linear in any way. 

2. There's something wrong w the plug and I'd suggest hitting up support about it.

author: cy (sigh)
content:
specifically when I want to bring that kind of texture up - I'll usually 
1. find the range where it's sitting (soloing the band if needed) , 
2. set a band to that and start processing to get it to sound prominent. 
3. Once dialed in I'll play it w the track and adjust the level of the processed 

Another way would be to use freq specific saturation /distortion to create that texture and then blend it in in parallels.
I would play with more aggressive distortion algorithms in this case

author: cy (sigh)

Use and case.
- more odd harmonics to get the gritty stuff or more knock from the bass/low end
- more even Harmonics for control/sweetening

author: Maxim
content: Reason why is because you might be doing things unintentionally to your 808 sound. The image shows you 3 808s. Left is the 808 just clip gained down (what you might want to try for gainstaging into your limiter). Middle is your limiter saturation tactic (which sounds weird to me personally). And right is the same 808 with saturation added in a more thoughtful manner (in parallel just adding upper harmonics that sound better to me).

author: Maxim
content: So unless you’re really looking for that buzzy square wave 808 sound maybe you can view saturation and gainstaging as two different parts of the mixing process

author: Maxim
content: (But even then view the saturation with the limiter as that and not reducing gain)

author: spectrummasters
Eric Martin
content:
right, there was a spectral shaper on low mids on one of his buses, but then again on the mix bus it was doing the 1-6k.

I think from what I understand that JC is doing he is controlling the attack so it’s consistent, then using the transient shaper to make sure it’s the same for every hit. It is smart, and for his workflow it’s also fast and easy.

I use compressors a lot, but I’m also working in mostly indie rock with acoustic drums and bass guitars not 808’s and drum machines, which is a drastically different world. I also think I’m doing what most people don’t do and I don’t always love the artifacts of compression so I generally use slow attacks to maintain transients and fast releases to recover quickly (I adjust so that I get the fastest release before audible distortion)

BTW Bruce Swedien while he may have evangelized not using compression don’t underestimate that his greatest works were done to tape and even when you were conservative and didn’t hit tape hard, the transformers going into tape and out of and the tape as a medium itself would peak limit attack heavy instruments like drums

author: Eric Martin
content: for me it’s more of understanding what sounds good to my ears and how to make new stuff sound good, and when to choose distortion/saturation/compression/limiting/waveform manipulation and when not to.

But I guess the same can be said for a lot of mix processes!

author: ehutton21
content:
i just realized that i believe we’re talking about two different plugins! im using lift 3, I believe diamond transient is the one with the ability to clip in the mid range. i don’t have transient, but after my experience with using these across my mixes I’m pretty set on adding it to my arsenal. diamond lift 3 sounds big and powerful on bus and mastering duties. there’s a certain heft it adds in the clipping department that my other tools don’t have, but it’s compression and eq moves are actually quite versatile—it can be just as powerful but also surprisingly… musical?

i like compressor mode 3, clipped mode 1, and i gain stage the bus/track so i can drive the input on the plug-in, compress 1-2 db, drive the makeup gain of the compressor into the clipper so i’m on the verge of hitting the overs, then i gain match the plug-in to desired level. maybe add a little saturation there too. it’s got a subtle feel but it’s 👌🏼

my experience with this has been incredible with it on drum bus, music bus (albeit i’m not clipping), and mix bus especially when i get to the stem stage of my work in ableton (i do some stem work in ableton after doing the heavy lifting stuff in protools). pure insanity. 

i’m pretty disappointed that even with my mac m1 studio, acustica plugins in protools aren’t really running for me. gonna have to troubleshoot that.

author: rse
content: I get the idea of doing clipping in different stages, but I'm not sure if putting a clipper on everything is necessary. Some elements might not benefit from any form of clipping.

author: GoCrazyNate
content: The rough overview is basically hard clip loud bold elements (for me 808, heavy synths, snares, sometimes hi hats) and soft clip or saturate the quieter elements. This works beautifully for really simple & sparse production and as long as you keep an eye on transients you’re golden but I really just take the method as “don’t be afraid to clip shit instead of spamming Saturn 2 and spectre everywhere” and “clipping isn’t just for mastering and 808s”

author: Jeremy Klein
content:
Ok can someone help me understand this?

Take any random audio, throw a gain plugin on it and increase the volume by 40db. It's going to distort like crazy. As i understand it, it's not your DAW clipping it, its the audio leaving the daw and clipping your convertors. 

My guess is this is Hard/Digital Clipping. But when I export the audio in the above scenario and compare it with the same thing but with a hard clipper plugin on the master, they do not null out.

author: Jeremy Klein
content: So what kind of clipping is going on here, and how do I replicate it within the DAW?

author: rse
content: A hard clipper will behave differently than the digital clipping that occurs when you clip your converters or when you export a signal that exceeds 0db at a bit depth of 24bits. Your daw works internally at 32bits floating point, which means that your individual faders will have a lot of headroom above 0 db, so you can go pretty much as high as you want with them, as long as you turn the signal down in a later stage before it hits the final output. Otherwise you will be clipping your converters like you said. This clipping will be different for every converter, and it's why mastering guys buy converters that are worth more than your car, just so they can get a certain flavour when clipping their a/d (although I'm pretty sure most have stopped doing this, because it often just sounds like shit lmao). Clipping your signal with a plugin will introduce different distortion/saturation/artifacts. It will even be different between different plugins and between different algorithms inside of those plugins (if you are able to select those)  (some clipping plugins actually use the exact same algorithms, so those won't have any differences ofc. EDIT: the only differences here would be in the oversampling functionality etc. of the plugins used, not in the actual clipping algorithm. There actually aren't a lot of hard clipping algorithms out there, so most differences between plugins will be in the way the anti-aliasing filters work)

author: ALXCPH
content: I think there’s a video on YouTube, that pretty much proves what you said. It compares some free clippers. And some of the most expensive ones and they all null. 👀 let me see if I can find it later

author: Jeremy Klein
content: Ahhh thanks for the explanation! I thought with hard / digital clipping, there is no algorithm, it's just a flat line cutting off the top of the wave form. So each algorithm should be identical. (is my understanding).

author: rse
content:
Like I said I'm not 100% comfortable in clipping A/D converters, so I'm not sure what's going on here but it's interesting to know that that nulled in your test.

EDIT: I'm pretty sure I know what's going on here. You rendered the audio out, so what output you had selected wouldn't make a difference. The best way to test this would be to record the actual output from the Apollo and from your Mac. This way you will hear what the converters are doing, otherwise you're just clipping the sound by exporting it to 24 bit, which will always be the same.

author: ehutton21
content:
I’ve got sent a snare drum with mono compatibility issues, but not  in terms of its recorded nature (it was a sample, not mic’d off a drum kit). It’s clear that in the low mids, some kind of synthesis is going on with a distortion/feedback effect to add this ‘diving’ sine wave effect right before the transient of the snare connects (so it’s like if you had an open hat hitting right before the snare).
 
In mono, that low mid resonance effect disappears though, but the actual transient sound remains in tact.

Get really crazy and distort it, warp it, automate panning for it. You won’t think “oh wow chorus is golden” but if you have that 90% there already, a nice harmonic addition like that being tucked in nicely is just great on the ears man.

author: ehutton21
content:
Ahhh I see you’ve met my people—the bedroom artist! 

Jokes aside, I got into engineering because me and my friend could not afford to have someone decent mix our stuff, so I know the NT1A to 251 struggle well—he records exclusively on an NT1A. 

The biggest thing about working with bedroom-y vocals is they’re going to have their shortcomings, and maybe more so than most other mixes, you can process them quite a bit and you should. Do whatever RX work you need to do, and do that first. I don’t usually worry about playing the vocals with the track at this point, im just hunting for any pops, clicks, clips or room artifacts. 

Next for me is reamping—this may be odd to some people and their may not be a general consensus on how much it helps, but it gives me a sense of tonal consistency when I can set how I want the vocal to drive. If you have something that feels like how you would have tried to record it, it helps the psychological aspect IMO.

author: ehutton21
content: I have my vintech patched in to my I/O as like insert 3. Set a vocal preamp like it’s going to line, right, and you’re pretty much getting what you have ITB and running it through your transformers like you would if you had been there with the preamp. I’ve tried to read into this and the most I got was a GS thread about whether or not it degrades audio quality, and whatever I lose by running it through my preamp and distressor, I make up for in comfort and tonal familiarity. It won’t be a silver bullet but it’ll give you a blanket of “oh yeah ok I have this sound, that’s my transformer, I can work with that” and it isn’t necessarily a radical move like distortion

author: ehutton21
content: I did something real close to this! I used a synthesizer to create a sub harmonic at the low end range (30hz and below was lacking in the kick) and i layered it in with the kick at a barely audible level. author: ehutton21

author: NoahNeedleman
content: Settings change per source for me- but I generally reach for it when I’m looking for a real snappy electric or spitty vocal. I’m pretty partial to the UAD 1176 over CLA or BF, but I love the UAD 176 and 175-b when I’m looking for extra sauce… the more you drive those the better they sound, and it’s hard to make it too pumpy, whereas the 1176 it’s hard to make it *not* pumpy. That’s just me though. I’ve been accused of not going hard enough more than I have of going too hard, so keep that in mind.

author: Will Melones
content: I only ask because I've had that experience of 1176ing on the way in and coming back a day later to hear that take-killing distortion. Like who recorded this traaash, oh it was me?

author: BatMeckley
content: Also, because what else am I doing right now, I’ll tell you a real fun tip about 1176’s: they tend to have a real magic sweet spot, much like the way a good guitarist sets their amp for just the edge of breakup. The track comes alive with harmonics without being “woah that’s distorted”, and I’ve always viewed them more for that effect rather than just a “gain controller”If you have your own 1176 that you can really spend time with, you can figure out just where in the needle that magic happens. THEN you can use something ultra transparent and awesome like a Dave Hills titan to control dynamic on the way in and really increase your chances of keeping the vocal right in the magic spot without risking overs. 🪄 You can do it with a studio’s 1176, you just have to figure out the sweet spot before the artist gets there and be willing to adjust on the fly

author: ALXCPH
content:
Noticed something funny. The slowest attack on a SSL GComp is 30ms. 
30 ms is around 33hz, which is around 1 full cycle of the lowest perceivable musical note for us (B0). 

I wonder if thats why that setting is so popular. allowing a full cycle to develop, will lets us hear that pure sinewave without distortion while still compressing. 

You could make presets for attack settings for all the 12 notes in the lowest octave. To always have the fastest attack that lets through at least one cycle of the lowest note in the song/key. 

I wonder if Letting the tempo decide the release to dictate the kind of groove/feel the song has. Maybe a Rythmic value? a 16th? and 8th? swung 16th or 8th? 

Food for thought. I know "use your ears" and i do, always. but i just noticed that i and others gravitate towards settings that land around these points of interest and or their multiples.

author: ALXCPH
content: saturation does behave differently, like if you are saturating your bass and drums together. but you can fix that by sidechaining your saturation plugin to both tracks and butting the plugin on each track. that way you will get the stems reacting like they were processed together but still printed individually

author: ALXCPH
content:
From a neuroscience perspective, the essence of the ongoing debate is: Is the mind purely biological, or is the mind a meta-biological process? Most neuroscientists are strict materialists, and believe there is no such thing as mind at all—that mind is an epiphenomenon of biological processes (in other words, it’s all biology.)

A small minority hold fast to the idea that the mystery of consciousness is something beyond neurochemistry and neuroscience. It’s very elusive to describe what mind is, once you remove yourself from the biological debate.

There is no evidence to suggest otherwise. Neuroscientists, like all scientists, are quantitatively driven. If you can’t measure it, it doesn’t exist. Since you can’t measure mind, you can’t quantify mind—so by definition, it’s not physical. If it isn’t physical, then either it doesn’t exist and is just an illusion, or we have to establish that there is a reality that we can’t measure. And that’s where the fulcrum of this debate actually is—how do you know something exists if it’s not measurable?

author: ALXCPH
content: @Nomograph Mastering you said something I found interesting. You play with the attack time of the PRO L if you want something more or less aggressive. Does that mean that you don’t do any clipping before hitting the pro L?

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: The decision whether to use a hard clipper before Pro L2 is super easy. If there are big poky transients like snares then clipping works really well to keep that energy but control it (really we spread it across the frequency spectrum). If the mix is more dense and steady state then clippers don’t work

author: ALXCPH
content: I like to do a little clipping of the biggest transients before the pro L and then leave the attack of the pro L at 0, that way I control the clipping first with one plug-in and then just limit with pro L, and use the release setting to determine aggressiveness/looseness

author: Deleted User
content:
Same here. And I also went on no compressor route, not only because Jon said he doesn’t use one but I’ve had similar experiences as Jon of running things through compressors to be either disappointed or to be unsure if it was better or not. 

I started using compressors again at some point but I found better tools to achieve what I was hoping to get out of using a compressor through the process of not using any compressor. Now I grab compressor only when I want compressor pump/pinch or tame pokey transients without adding too much harmonics. 

During the early phase of this, I was going overboard with saturation and driving stuff and started dialing back a bit.

Cian’s mix bus curve and saturn preset changed the way I mix, I’m now less heavy handed and can start from a place of having things sound pretty good- but I do end up having to bypass or back off on them every now and then. 

Trying these things made me occasionally deliver something weird at first but in the big picture, they benefited me.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Are they apparent when all of the mics are in? Sometimes that stuff is better addressed on the bus. Have you engaged drum bus processing (if any)? Sometimes thickening and/or darkening the drum bus (Pultec 100Hz, Studer Tape, whatever) renders this upper mid/high stuff less abrasive.

Sometimes addressing too much of this stuff sucks life out of drums. I leave most mad snare ringing in as I work on the drums - it often winds up being cool stuff to add to the pumping energy with heavier parallel compressors, or distortions.

Is it apparent/interfering with the mix as a whole?

yeah. Electronic music and EDM producer have been doing this for a while, some “self mastering” producers actually just put stuff out this way- print shit clipping and call it a day, and it sounds fine.

author: Jeremy Klein
content:
i brought this up in this discord months ago and it's still the last piece of audio voodoo i dont understand. 

When it goes above zero in your DAW and you print it like that, its not a straight line digital clip which i _think_ i verified by null testing and blind listening. 

i've done a few blind listening tests between clipper and just going above zero in your DAW, and in some mixes, i can pick out the above zero version as """better""" above random chance. and this is with a bunch of different clipping algorithms.

author: ALXCPH
content:
Imagine you are a dj and the dj before you played super loud so you want to compete and even turn up the heat, so now you are really maxing the output of your mixer(the speakers have insane headroom, so nothing is distorting like crazy) if you play y a track at -11 with hard hitting transients in the middle of -3 lufs tracks it will sound weaker as it will be quieter. And since you can’t turn up the output on your mixer the audience will only notice the loss of energy… they don’t care about the transients, they want loud and want energy. That’s why the loudness thing is still a thing and always will be in the EDM world. 


This is a huge over simplification, and there are of course exceptions. 

But in the end, people will just naturally go for loud. People turn up to level match and never down.

this seems like they’re just passing the buck onto the next playback system to get clipped instead of handling it themselves.

It’s also “the sound” of that music so it ultimately doesn’t matter because it’s all clipped somewhere at some point anyway. And that’s kinda what that music sounds like already, it already sounds crunchy and clipped so more clipping isn’t gonna hurt it. Anymore than it already is.

🤷

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Not quite. The clipping will be “imprinted” on the file once he prints an 16 or 24 bit fixed point file. But for sure intersample peaks in codecs will be significant later. Actual DAC intersample peaks get rarer as everyone is using digitally attenuated volume controls in their cars, phones, sonos etc

author: Adam Thein
content:
Interface to interface - you'll want to research a good stable interface with a reputation for good windows support.  RME is one of them, MOTU is generally fairly stable on Windows.  I had good luck with Audient for a few years, Focusrite was not stable.

In generally Core Audio makes audio an absolute breeze - you don't really have to think about "are my drivers up to date?  will this update to Windows be compatible with my interface drivers?"

Over time it definitely has gotten better on Windows but my day to day ease of use on Mac with Core Audio plugging things in - routing audio around with Blackhole for remote sessions, unplugging an interface swapping interfaces, general stability is WAY higher on MacOS imo

author: stefanmacc
content:
There are others here that can probably answer this better. But IMO you don’t want to rely on the limiter as a way to achieve loudness or excitement in a mix because you’ll likely end up with a crushed muddy mess… The limiter is not very good at those jobs.

Also LUFS is perceived loudness meaning EQ plays a huge role in that.. Distortion / Saturation plays a big role..  

So limiting should be one slice of the pie when it comes to achieving level… the rest should be done within the mix with the correct EQ moves . Correct distortion and some compression (not too much)

author: stefanmacc

author: spectrummasters
content: There’s so many different loudness strategies imo (from arrangement right through to a master). Some folks parallel everything and filter it all...some smash the hell out of clippers and limiters. One thing I’d recommend is a Jon Castelli tip.  The use of transient shaping after saturation/compression is v useful. I always suggest the same videos for studying approaches to punch and loudness....but they are decent and relevant. Do “Jon Castelli mixes TShyne” for a study in saturation and clipping......and MixedbyAli mixes YG Surgery for a study in balancing and busing .

author: CK
content: just gonna throw this out there...Try the God Particle as your only mix bus plugin.  Use all the sweet spot targets, and forget about how much it is limiting.  Focus on getting the EQ targets dialed in with your mix, and the input target not clipping..  This taught me SO much about loudness.  My mixes consistently hit -9rms and -9 lufs when I get them dialed with EQ, and I no longer get the "smushed" feeling I used to get when trying to get loud. The mix actually breathes and is loud AF. Then when I get the eq targets dialed in, I see where I am hitting large amounts of peaks over 3-4db on the limiter, and then I address those peaks at the source in different ways. The God Particle I truly think can be a teaching tool, as well as a great sounding mix bus tool. I am now using it less and experimenting with my own chains. But seriously, this may help you as it helped me. The GP does not suck and I will always have it in the bag as sometimes it is just the right sauce.

author: stefanmacc
content: Nice okay , so to experiment with the idea of getting loudness or excitement without limiting … solo your drum bus and put the stock Lo-Fi on it. And turn up the bottom left “distortion” to 2-3 db and notice what it does to the peak level out of the plug-in vs coming in… you’ll notice it looks like it’s been limited. But it’s not. It’s just smashing the transients down and maintaining or gaining perceived loudness at the same time.

author: Rob Domos
content: This is also the biggest reason hardware EQ’s are still preferable. People think it’s the “analog vibe” their into, or whatever, and I’m sure occasionally they are going for those saturation artifacts, but the biggest benefit by far is the fact that in the analog domain, phase delay and group delay differential are not bottlenecked by samplerate, so they can be far more linear

author: stefandurandt
content: I use an Analog VU meter on the output of my monitor controller built by the inhouse tech who also worked at Neve (he designed and built the 8816 summing box) - he recommended the Sifam ones because their ballistics are really good - which I think is the main argument for analog vs digital. I started using them itb after Leon Zervos who masters at 301 where I work but used to work at Sterling (where he mastered classics like mambo nr 5, the macarena, Avril Lavigne, Maroon 5 etc.) recommended them & spoke about the same “dancing” thing that @spectrummasters spoke about. After that I also got another 2  lessons by 301 mastering engineers (one who’s won like 19 aria - australian grammies & been nominated for like 90) - once where I gave a floortom too much bottom end $ & that really triggered a mastering compressor limiting him in some way & he showed me how the left side jumped on the vu - I didn’t hear it at all in the mixing room but could hear it clearly in the mastering room. The other engineer showed me the same thing this time with a powerful lead vocal. This was kinda back when the loudness wars were still a bit more relevant & when I delivered quiter mixes & left them more space to do their thing & these energy bursts limited the final loudness potential. Then I saw that same Jacquire King thing & together all this made me think of how useful the VU is if you’re working in less than ideal bass monitoring environment - it really shows the bass energy in a pretty unique way. I like listening to references (check the bass VU on for instance Jon Castelli’s Khalid Talk vs Sza Low - one very kick focused & one super sub focussed - both a fuckton of low end vs Serban Blinding Lights try -7 as the reference - BL hovers around 0 & is louder lufs wise & then try Fleetwood Mac Dreams (I think the 2012 remaster) - softer, nice transients, beautiful bass - being driven by Kick,snare & bass) - all of those “dance” with the groove.

author: lystell
content:
On the topic of EQ
I'm doing some projects now that are live drums driven so to speak. I'm trying to up my game both when it comes to recording and mixing. 
My instinct when it comes to EQ is to subtract. In a way, it feels logical to me. Let's say I don't like the sound on a snare around 400hZ. Then my brain goes - let's remove that. 
I've been digging deeper lately into the API style of EQ and it occurred to me that when going through the preset list -  most of the presets were doing additive stuff. I find this very interesting and when it comes to "surgical sounddesign",  a new workflow for me. Like - I don't like the low mid on this snare. Let's boost the top instead. 
It feels somewhat backward but I can see some good things coming of it. 
How's your workflow?

author: cian riordan
content:
Guitar:
* Reduce the main guitar volume slightly throughout the song and better blend it: The guitar is just going through a phase – it wants to be heard, but not too much, and it's looking for a blending partner.
* Make the guitar solo sit more on top of the mix: The guitar solo wants to be the star of the show, like a diva in the spotlight. Lights, camera, action!
* Experiment with sound design and cool effects for a more theatrical guitar solo: Why play a guitar solo when you can have a one-man rock opera in the middle of the song?
* A bit too much overdrive, consider reducing: Less overdrive? But the guitar likes to live life on the edge, where "clean" is just a four-letter word.
* Decrease the volume of the single-note guitar walk-down at 2:39 and blend them into the background: Because sometimes, even guitars need to take a step back and chill with the background singers.

author: Maxim
content:
“The Inflator is not the same as the Enhance feature in the Oxford Limiter, although the effects might be considered similar. In simple terms, the Inflator is a special kind of distortion generator which has no dynamic activity over time. It's a static process. It gives the impression of loudness by providing the harmonic cues we associate with loud and stressed sounds, increasing the harmonic density of the material in a way that is sympathetic to the ear.

The Oxford Limiter's Enhance function is a special kind of 'dynamic' process that does not add distortion to steady state signals. It works over time, programme history, peak and average levels and left/right stereo differences to limit the signal and squash peak events, while providing the listener with the impression that the peaks are still there. It can sympathetically remove peak events so that you can provide more transparent limiting, or make the programme even louder without causing sample value overs.”

author: Maxim
content:
And from the manual:
“The enhance process improves the perceived loudness and presence of the programme material by modifying the dynamic and harmonic content of the signal. Since the method used is different from the Pre-Processing section, it can further enhance the perceived volume of a previously processed signal, while suppressing all signal overloads. As the limiting action does not involve conventional sample value clipping, harsh distortions are avoided, and programme detail and dynamic information is largely retained.

Also, since the plug-in has internal headroom, transient levels greater than notional maximum modulation can pass from the Limiter section into the enhancement stage. This means that percussive overshoots, that would normally be lost in a conventional limiter (or would give rise to overloads), may be included within the sonic results of the plug-in, producing both richer dynamic sonic detail and a useful reduction in the perceived artefacts of the limiting process, all without giving rise to any sample value overload.

This property enables slower attack times to be used in the Pre-Process section, without creating output overloads, which would otherwise result in a need to reduce output levels.”

author: Slow Hand
content:
I'm a big fan of Goodhertz *Tupe* for parallel distortion. While it's not going to be the right flavor for every situation they implement it well. It has an excellent *Emphasis* section that allows you to emphasize/de-emphasize frequencies going into and coming out of the distortion circuit. 

This means that you can get the entire source sound to hit the distortion circuit evenly. Akin to making it fit your sound like a glove and saturate very evenly, rather than having the bass blow out the distortion before your mids or high-end can be saturated. Then I blend to taste with the dry/wet fader in the plugin.

author: JustinLeu
content:
Everything @Edward Rivera mentioned. It is a very helpful tool, but I think it can be abused and yield a terrible result even if the waveform looks "nice and even" haha.... For instance, you are seeing a waveform that is made of the entire frequency spectrum and the amplitude will be different depending on the sound/frequency makeup of each word. When you just "make it look even" and play it back, many times it sounds worse than before. Full-band and multi-band compression+saturation can sound much more natural, and is wayyyy less time consuming. You are able to get a result very quickly and remain objective. 

Clipgain is very useful...just something to be aware of!

author: spectrummasters
content: ...im aiming for the dynamic range between the moments where the kick and bass hit seperately...to when they hit together....to be my low end dynamic overall (if that makes sense)....so i dont want to flatten that range there....and instead prefer to compress the kick and bass seprately on their own buses . Im using parrallels of my kick and bass to get my loudness and harmonics, pre Low End Bus . If id want more control id consider a hz-dependent side chain on the bass from the kick, but dont like how that f's with the attack of the bass. Trying to do less processing at all stages......and get there with better balancing ..... So...a tiny bit of  comp on the kick and bass buses (0.5 db slow attack, fast release...usually neutron comp) and only an eq and standard clip on the kick bass bus to only catch random peaks and not jam the final  limiter . i like a littler expansion also , playing around with the pro G expnasion mode is fun

author: BoozleBAM

author: JustinLeu
content:
Id be happy to listen as well bro! Hard to say what will be right without hearing it.

-EQ and levels are a given...so apart from that...
-Light ratio compression on busses + master (light ratio like 1.25-2:1 allows you to keep things in compression and still feel natural)
-Purposeful reverb/delay to make a believable space 
-Don't be afraid to try a short verb on the 2bus
-Stages of saturation

The biggest thing for sparse/soft arrangements is making the space it lives in believable (if it supposed to feel natural)

author: JustinLeu
content:
Clippers can be great on busses. Great on drums etc… I find Standard Clip to be super intuitive to use and you can visualize what is happening. (Probably helpful if you are trying to gain understanding)

On the mixbus it can be helpful before the limiter but most of the time I would introduce it towards the end of a mix if at all. I would try hard clipping or a more gentle knee and see if between that and a limiter I can get something better than limiting alone.

Keep in mind that any saturation plugin (tube/tape) on the mix bus is “clipping” (soft clipping) and I find that gain staging in to that type of processing is more friendly to mix in to rather than hard clipping.

author: sinaigimenez
content:
Hi @cian riordan I've been exchanging a couple of mails with Greg Norman, from Electrical Audio and I thought his response could be useful for you or any other guys here with a 351. I'm going to add that output attenuator but I'll leave the unit stock. I love the way it sounds! Now I'm curious to hear the ones modded for Electrical Audio though. Did you have the chance to hear them during the St. Vincent recording? Anyway, this is what Greg said about it:
Hello,

Yes, my typical modification will change the sound of the preamplifier. The distortion and noise is much lower when the conversion is done. If you are happy with the way yours sounds, you could simply add an output attenuator, like you say. There is a part that is popular in the DIY world for making 1176s.  It is a 3-section 600 ohm “T-pad” potentiometer. You can find it on the Capi website.  
If your unit does not currently have a 600 ohm output load resistor, you may want to add a switch to engage the attenuator. Simply having it in the circuit will load the output with 600 ohms. This might lower the headroom and change things a little bit. 

Good luck with your project,

Greg Norman

author: peterlabberton
content:
I’m not gonna dig through search or anything like that, but @M3MIYAGI, here’s what I’ve been doing for the last several years more or less (still refining/tweaking but basically the same). A lot of it stolen from @cian riordan and from this Discord, lots of wisdom from @Nomograph Mastering included.

Minimal buss compression (1-3db on loudest sections of a mix), usually some kind of tape saturation (typically Slate Virtual Tape Machine), and Pro L2. The limiter is only grabbing 3-4 dB for the most part with the odd drum hit or whatever hitting more. Rarely I’ll add in other processing to push things harder for a specific mix, but 95% of the time that’s it. Then it’s sub busses or processing on individual tracks to get the level and compression/limiting needed to get things slamming. Then for mastering I pull the gain on Pro L2 down 6 dB, print and call it a day.

author: peterlabberton
content: Just to experiment, I’d say try distributing some of that limiting across different busses. Try limiting or clipping the drum buss a few db, maybe another small amount across all the instruments but not the vocals…

author: Jonathan Jetter
content:
If loudness is a goal, then it's usually good to navigate that in the mix instead of waiting until mastering.

Also think it's often good to split the load across tracks vs. subgroups vs. the 2-mix, and to split the load between compression, saturation, limiting, clipping on various elements/groups/master.

Figuring out all of the above is easier with a limiter at the end.

author: Deleted User
content: I don’t measure, but the way I do it is to have a fixed reference at -23LUFS. I’m taking -23 reference tracks, turning my monitor controller to where it feels good (not too loud, not too quiet) and start mixing from there. Doing it this way means I have to take down my stems quite a lot at the beginning, but in return I can push things very drastically without clipping unintentionally. But you can take any reference you want, I just like to have loads of headroom at the start of a mix

author: Deleted User
content: So it’s basically just for the first half of the mix I’d say, where I’m more free to push things until I put the limiter on and mix like everyone else with clipper and limiter getting the density, but still at the same reference volume on my monitor controller cause I’m using the l2 in 1:1 mode, which I dissengage at the end of the mix so I hit peak loudness

author: river

Ableton chain 
Two chains, one called, left one called right. Pan each to the respective channel.
Left channel, invert phase, distortion plugin, invert phase again,
Right channel have the same distortion settings (or similar) 
It will create some difference between the two channels due to how the distortion plugin reacts (non linear process)

author: bobby k
content: i've dealt with this a fair amount, but never thought to mention it here. For better or worse, I often end up with pretty air-tight first passes on the gainstaiging front. So sometimes, when a mix note is as simple as "turn up 808", the rest of the mix changes for obvious reasons. I'm hitting my multiband different, hitting my clipper different, hitting my limiter different; so if I were to simply execute that note, now the vocal, guitar, pretty much everything shifts a good bit in energy and I then spend time making the mix work again now that a big chunk of energy got pushed up in it. (side note - I like to mix a bit more gentle/tight on the low-end side since the lows are so hot in car systems, headphones, entertainment centers, etc. these days. Midrange is my home base.) Curious what your experiences have been with this sort of thing, and/or if you have recommendations.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
@cian riordan If there are multi-tracked drums, I'll usually do my whole process of leveling, phase checking, quick EQ voicing on those first. Then go to the loudest part of the song and quickly audition maximizer vs. vintage lim vs. Pro-L2 to get things to hit ~-9 LUFS on my Clarity M loudness radar (really great visualization for quickly doing this). Then I just get to work on the mix. Things often end up getting louder throughout the process and I'm OK with that. I'm often going back and checking to make sure things aren't overcooked. I should change my language from 'set it and forget it' to 'set it, forget it, but go back and check every now end then'.”

Will the drum levelling prior to checking those loud sections include clipping / limiting on the drum bus?

author: cian riordan
content: Its often the case that in this process, I'm driving the master bus limiter WAY too hard to get it up to -9 in this initial setup... but thats when I'll go back and start fine tuning the compression/clipping structure of the drums to relieve the pressure off the master bus limiter (or bus compression) without losing the overall level.

author: Ross Fortune
content: Right. I’ve found that difficult - trying to eek out headroom in reverse like that, rather than factoring clipping and limiting in as I’m building the drum sound

harmonics, non linearities, noise floor, are pretty much the only technical difference as far as I know.  (someone please chime in if I'm messing up)

the other part is work flow. touching knobs and not seeing exact numbers inherently makes most ppl move on instinct /intuition a lot more (trust their ears).

folks that use analog modeled stuff is mostly cause they get most (or enough ) of the benefits from analog + recall + unlimited instances

author: James Cronier
content:
Standard Clip question for those who use it: 

Why is the soft clipping % slider adding so much gain? Am I missing something? 

When I use a clipper on tracks or mix bus, I always use it where the gain isn’t changed, and the threshold of the clipping just gets pushed down. Kclip, limitless, or Elysia Aphla comp clipper all allow this to be a one click operation regardless of soft knee settings.

When hard clipping, the clip fader Standard Clip behaves as expected, but as soon as I mess with the soft clipping the gain goes through the roof.

author: Edward Rivera
content: I believe only soft clip pro does that, I could (very well) be wrong

author: Rollmottle
content: you mean the saturator slider? the saturator slider is pretty aggressive. it's like OTT. you can combo that with the sliders on the left to apply saturation and press the saturated signal into the clipper. adjust gain down to compensate for any gain added with the saturator.

author: Will Pragnell
content: if memory serves it’s knee adjustment in one mode but does more in the other soft clip mode (i think pro)

author: Will Pragnell
content: just had a quick play in plugin doctor - it is knee adjustment in both soft clip modes, but it also increases the gain of the signal below the clipping threshold (in both, though the gain curve is different in each)

author: shaunobi
content:
I use it and love it.

Near then end of a mix, I'll check it (in fine-grained mode, usually on the "bass heavy" curve). If I'm already sitting in the curve, I just leave it alone. If I'm a little out here and there (usually in the upper mids / highs for me) I'll put an eq (usually Weiss EQ MP or Pro Q3 - something that's not going to add "analog" saturation) right before it and make the changes it's suggesting, watching it to see if I got it close.

I think flip the EQ off and on to see if I like it more or less. Maybe half the time I DO like it more, though I often "back it off" a little, such that I'm like 50% or 70% of the way to what it's saying would be a "normal" mix.

The other ~half of the time I'm like "naw, don't like that" and disable the EQ.

I suppose I could saturate to my heart’s content but I wouldn’t mind going a bit weird with it instead and creating a parallel “everything” send before the mix bus with something like an echorec, echorec, space echo, or even a room emulator to add a bit of life into it, glue things together and give it a bit of a band-in-the-room feel. author: Jack
content:
Going to assume you’re talking more Rumours than Aerosmith.

Drums: dbx 160, transient designer on close mics to thud things up, Fabfilter Saturns ‘dynamics’ knob works quite well to tighten things too, no slammin’ compression on room mics/overheads, sometimes hi-passing overheads into being ‘cymbal mics’ and giving the close mics their space 

Vocals: Dolby trick, not always super aggressively hi-passed, H3000/Microshift backing vocals

Guitars: acoustic 12 string layers, phasers/flangers, mid-forward drives, acoustic guitars often super hi-passed 

Bass: flatwound strings, picked 

Annoying answer: it’s mostly in the arrangement

author: Joey O’Gorman
content: Any suggestions to fix a clipped vocal? I’ve tried RX de-clip and de-crackle, and Audacity. Seems like it might be unsaveable. (For context I heard it when recording so I switched the preamp and got less clipping but she didn’t perform half as well as the first time and they/we’d preferred the first ones - I hadn’t had this issue using the CM87 mic before but probably should’ve tested a few just didn’t have much time)

author: masteredbyjack
content:
You could try spectral repair replace on some of the distortion (it may not work but can). Ive also found that this sort of thing can actually be better repaired in a full mix print than just on the vocal itself, my theory is that spectral replacements has more to grab from and it’s less obvious then

Of course I say all this without hearing it, there are cases I’ve seen where it can’t be saved from what I know

author: masteredbyjack
content:
I’ve found best results (mainly when I have had to do it on a mix but every once in a blue moon someone will send a vocal like this for me to look at before mastering) if you go in and select each bit of distortion, usually they appear as vertical lines and replace them separately and slowly

It can be painstaking but often the results are worth it (though there is of course a trade off it’s not perfect)

author: Mike Tierney
content: In that case, it's most likely just the timbre of the bassoon. Bassoon is kind of a funny instrument, it has a really wide note range but tends to have a slightly nasal-y tone because it naturally accentuates some of its harmonics. Some bass guitars kind of have this phenomenon, where even when they play an open E which should be 41Hz, you hear the harmonic more clearly at 82Hz

author: Sei046
content:
I’m struggling with some vocals that have a sort of “grain” or distortion in the top end.  Something around the 6-7k region but it extends across most of the top end.  I didn’t notice it really when tracking. It’s paired with a very low mid heavy vocal so it’s making adding high end and clarity difficult. I blamed my chain for days but when I opened another vocal done through the exact same chain the following day from another artist it was like butter so it’s obviously inherent to the vocal which makes sense in hindsight.  

Any ideas on how to bring out some more clarity in the top end and not exaggerate that? I’ve tried sooth, had a brief look at declicking in rx, spectre. What’s worked the best so far has been using Accentize spectral balancer to clamp the top end and then clariphonic to bring it back up and that has helped. 

It’s the sort of thing you’d imagine rx to reduce the noisy component in that frequency range would help but your air is essentially a noisy component. 

Anyone ever came across this grain? 

The style of music doesn’t demand crazy top end so I could just embrace the warmth but I’d love a bit more articulation. 

Sorry for the long post

author: Ross Fortune
content:
I’ve got a high energy, high tempo track with a snare (real kit) that’s feels tuned too low for the song. Or maybe the wrong drum altogether. 

My instinct all the way through the mix has been trying to eek more crack out of this gooshy snare, with limited success. Tried EQing more upper mid, Saturn to do same, parallel sansamp, compression on the close mics / on the drum bus / drum bus parallels and combos of both, but the crack the song is wanting just isn’t part of the character of the snare. 

I’ve tried a bunch of samples but I can’t get them to marry with the character of the recorded drums.

The only mix note that’s come back is to make the snare more aggressive, which I’m translating to mean what I’m describing above. 

Are there any stones I haven’t turned?

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Have you tried something like hard clipping the snare (a parallel channel) with something like Standardclip - no oversampling. Then using a steep Linear phase high pass filter to get rid of the fundamental and maybe even the second harmonics entirely

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: So it’s just harmonically related, but shifting the energy up

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: LP EQ will be blurry but maybe this approach gives you enough extra upper harmonic energy to be worth it

author: Ross Fortune
content:
I have not. I’ve done transient designer into a clipper, but not the high passing.

When you say on a parallel channel, do you mean feeding a parallel channel with whatever grouping of snare close mics I’m using, and just applying this processing to thag parallel?

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: I would actually try a regular minimum phase EQ too, but steep, like 36 db/Oct. the phase relationships will be very off but because the harmonics are so different it might not matter

content: I'm mixing a indie band rock song which has a bunch of electric guitar tracks playing chords and solo, and they're so edgy and unpleasant at the mid and high range. author: vostral
content: It is already processed by EQ, Comp (CLA-2a, CLA-76), Saturn & Ozone Exciters, soothe2. I even reduced the Attack using SPL Transient

author: spookydrums
content: I'm struggling a bit with a vocal for an album I'm mixing at the moment. It's a female singer, sort of in a post-Phoebe Bridgers world or something like that. The vocal recording have this layer of what I think of as grainy distortion over them that feels sort of seperated from the actual meaningful musical information, and when I try to polish them up and make them nice and big and beautiful this pops out even more. Also, there's pronounced proximity effect on them as well, so I sort of feel like I can't work effectively with the top end and I can't make them big in the low mids either and just whatever I do sort of make them a little worse. Don't love the feeling, haha. Anyways, how would you guys go on about something like this?

author: spookydrums
content:
Yeah, love soothe, using it to control  the low mid resonances on this thus far. Maybe I could dig in a bit harder for the highs with it. Bloom didn’t work, it made it sound a bit more plastic-y and actually made the grainyness more pronounced. I haven’t gotten good results with bloom on female vocals so far, but I know that one day it will be just the thing needed. I think that probably RX will yield the best results, but for some reason I find myself resisting digging in with RX on this, probably because I know it’s going to be hard work and I’m a little lazy. Good lazy, though, because if I’m not I try too hard and end up taking away what’s good. 

I don’t have Ozone, but maybe this is what will push me over the edge to try it, hmmm. 

I was thinking that maybe some sort of tape thing could work, but I couldn’t get it to work with Tupe inmediately and the UAD Ampex made it brighter and more distorted. It kind of feels like it’s already on the edge of breaking up too much and becoming unpleasant, a bit like being touched softly on the arm when you have a fever and it’s almost painful. Hmm, now I’m just blabbering on. I’ll stop for now. Thank you for your suggestion!

author: spookydrums
content: These are all the right questions. Thank you. The problem is that it’s not static, it feels sort of too closed on soft wowels and too open on hard wowels, and the esses are breaking up into broadband distortion a lot of the time. I know I’ll have to get in there and sort of manifacture an effortlessness with clip fx, and I’m just resisting opening up that particular door because I know it’s going to be hard work. But yes, this just convinced me to roll up my sleeves and get in there. Thanks again, plus I don’t need a silver bullet, I just need to get on with it instead of talking about it.

author: onanisland
content:
Generalizing here without context but usually a "ballad piano" to me is in the softer spectrum, so sometimes desicion making is > check stereo image to lock in perspective > use an eq or something that doesnt overally emphasise the 3-4khz range > sometimes a Vari-Mu can ride the piano really well and give the warmth - and don't overdo it, Cinematic Rooms or VSS4 reverb for a realistic-ish space placement.

For cutting more though the mix I second spectre for brightness, but I also like the harrison EQ, it has really musical curves to get it to cut through without sounding "too much"

author: corporalconsequently
content:
Sincerely sorry if I'm bothering everyone again- just to be sure,
I have these three options, I'm confused so asking here, which one should I go with

#1 Two Samsung T7 Shield SSDs (both 1TB) working as a “Main” drive and a “Mirror” Drive.
One HDD Seagate Ultra Touch 4TB mirrored to Backblaze every 30 days or so.
The “Main” and “Mirror” Drives get shelved once they reach 95% capacity, and the “Main” drive is then backed up onto the HDD.
I buy a new pair of Samsung T7 Shield SSDs

#2 Two Samsung T7 Shield SSDs (both 1TB) working as a “Main” drive and a “Mirror” Drive.
One SSD WD Blue (m2 NVME) 1TB with a UGREEN m2 NVME 10GBPS enclosure or a ROG Ally Strix m2 NVME 10 GBPS enclosure mirrored to Backblaze.
The “Main” and “Mirror” Drives get shelved once they reach 95% capacity, and the “Main” drive is then backed up onto the WD SSD.
The WD SSD is shelved as it is backed up to Backblaze.
I buy a new pair of Samsung T7 Shield SSDs as well as a new WD SSD Blue 1TB

#3 Two SSDs WD Blue (m2 NVME) 1TB with a UGREEN m2 NVME 10GBPS enclosure or a ROG Ally Strix m2 NVME 10 GBPS enclosure working as a “Main” drive and a “Mirror” Drive.
One HDD Seagate Ultra Touch 4TB mirrored to Backblaze every 30 days or so.
The “Main” and “Mirror” Drives get shelved once they reach 95% capacity, and the “Main” drive is then backed up onto the HDD.
I buy a new pair of SSDs WD Blue 1TB.

author: Rollmottle
content: Backblaze seamlessly backs up any USB, TB and internal disks attached to your computer. Having to rely on remembering to re-connect drives regularly is a recipe for having your backup strategy fail. Shelving drives is fine, but if Backblaze doesn't see a disk in the pool of disks you've been backing up to it for 30 days, that disk will no longer be backed up. Which is another reason why you should aim for a higher capacity main drive.

Wouldn’t it depend entirely on what the curves on the clippers look like? I would think it would be different than stacking 2 identical limiters which would (I think) be the same as limiting the same amount with just one instance. Short version:
If the curves are identical it would not make sense to stack.

If the curves are different…it may make sense?

author: JustinLeu
content:
Right, one of the frustrating things about it is that it sounds like it is doing more than it shows.

If you hyper focus it in one area and then listen to the delta, that can be the best way to address the annoying resos. And not have it mess with stuff you want in the signal.

If there is just one or two dissonant harmonics on a vocal mic that you never want in the signal, a notch filter is way better.

If it is an overall poorly tracked or annoying vocal, 1 or 2 strategic instances of soothe can really sort it out most of the time.

author: spectrummasters
content:
Q for the gang , I’d be interested on hearing any strategies re : 
How do you handle a mix where the lead vocal is consistently powerful from the first verse, but the band’s dynamics follow a quiet verse/loud chorus structure?

Pulling the vocal down in the verse to match the band makes the chorus feel off, since the singer didn’t actually sing at a different level  in either section I had this situation for the last project I just finished and ended up splitting the (needed ) difference on level for the vocal between sections and adding saturation in the chorus, which worked — but I’d love to hear how others approach this kind of mismatch in vocal vs. band dynamics

author: onanisland

Listening at low levles helps a lot with balancing throughout, solo safe against other instruments / groups to find what to cut to make space for vocals  (with time you'll find this to be intuitive), I'll add something to the convo, when I had new assistants in to help them place the vocal I'd tell them to solo drums + bass + vocals and adjust level of the vocals - and that'd be a great a starting point, additonally I'd have them press the mono button with everything playing on the controller and listen at conversational level to ride it, and sometimes I'd suggest to create a "harmonics" group with all the gtrs, piano, banjos whatever and just see what the mids of those would sound like vs vocal, if they put spreader/doubler, we'd check sides only too

author: Slow Hand
content:
Conceivably any vocoder would be sufficient because the harmonic richness depends on the carrier signal you feed into it, which could easily be any bright synth that you have on hand.

That said, even if you have a darker carrier signal you can usually “tilt” the vocoder bands towards more high end energy and less low end if you want it brighter.

Have you tried Izotope’s *Vocal Synth 2*? It has lots of vocoder-adjacent effects that will do similar things.

author: Gabriel Tyranny
content:
Oh interesting - For some reason my journey has led to me only reaching for the CLA76 on a parallel for the bass, but I should try it again in other contexts.

In case anyone would wanna try my approach to getting bass to play nice across more speakers / phones:

- I use the 20 ratio bluey to squash a bass parallel. Then I drive it through the free TSC 808 plugin for further emphasize the harmonics the bluey brings out. (EQ too)
- Then, I use Audreio on the master to play the mix through my phone instead of my monitors. Once on the phone, you can blend the parallel with the bass in a way where there’s little to no audible difference on a monitor, but the illusion of a bass can be heard through the harmonics playing on the phone.
- It’s a balancing act, but there’s almost always a nice sweet spot to be found where it doesn’t change the quality of the sound enough to be intrusively perceived on HD speakers, while giving life to the bass on lesser speakers.

This has helped my bass translate to more systems, and is the only time I find myself wanting to use the CLA76.

author: Juliette

I was sitting down and researching, trying to figure out why my guitar trackings whilst using DI + amp sims had this particular harshness to it. 

Felt like I was going crazy until a particular YouTube video pointed it out: digital harshness. 

Makes the guitar sound great on its own if you’re just jamming, but that grit in the 5k to 10k range is too gnarly whilst sitting within the mix. I am so glad to have figured out what it is and shaved it down but man. It’s wild how you’ll *hear* that something doesn’t sound right but you don’t know what to even call it.

author: Ed Sokolowski
content:
SNR thing is somewhat overblown IMO, especially these days. Background noise is going to be quite a lot louder than A/D noise unless you have a really old interface, or really quiet signal. Even in ideal conditions, DI’s are unlikely to have more than 100dB in dynamic range.

There’s also a thing where a lot of amp sims need REALLY high (like un-intuitively loud) signals. To reach “unity” gain in Softube’s Marshalls or a lot of Amplitube amps, you essentially need to be just below clipping and then boost another 10-15dB or so

author: Slow Hand
content:
I looked at the harmonic analysis of each of the three modes at three different gain settings: -6dB input, -0.03dB input, and +6dB input. 
# -6dB Input Level
## Clean Mode
Pretty much what you'd expect. 0 harmonics and some noise down around -200dB.

author: Slow Hand
content:
## Subtle Mode
Noise floor jumps up to -150dB, but no harmonics. I was expecting more, but alright.

author: Slow Hand
content:
## Warm Mode
A nice 1st order harmonic about -22dB quieter than the 100 Hz test tone. Nice.

author: Slow Hand
content:
# -0.03 dB Input Level
## Clean Mode
No change. Same as before.
## Subtle Mode
*Nooow* we're getting something. At around -3.5dB these harmonics start to bloom, but only in the range of -3.5dB to 0dB. At levels lower than that they disappear entirely.

author: Slow Hand
content:
## Subtle Mode
Additional harmonics as you push it harder. Like you'd expect.

author: Brendan Trinkle
content:
Hi team, I've got a finger-style electric bass track in a mix that is a well played performance, but was inexpertly recorded on an instrument with some odd characteristics. The second harmonic is often louder than the fundamental, and any midrange available is just kind of clicky finger transient stuff. 

I've used RX to reduce the second harmonic to a more natural level (note by note), but the bass just still feels dark & doesn't cut on small speakers.

Re-recording the original player isn't an option, unfortunately. Are there any hive-mind suggestions to get more midrange character from a dark bass recording?

author: spookydrums
content: I feel like I get bass instruments with strong first and second harmonics, and also floor toms, a lot. I ususally dip a little in that frequency range and if it's a bass guitar what works for me to make it cut through more a lot of the time is Soundtoys Sie-Q with a healthy boost (think at around 3 o'clock) at 1.5 kHz. Oh, and SansAmp (the Audiopunks one is really good) can work wonders, either in-line or in parallell.

author: Jonathan Jetter
content: In general the SSL Native plugs seem to have more harmonic distortion than their 3rd party counterparts.

author: James Cronier
content:
I’ve been using the SSL native E-channel as a go to mixing insert on most every channel for the whole year. I turn off the VCA distortion by default (the extra THD is not welcome here). 

As a mixer, I find the stereo pan really useful in pro tools, the input/output gains handy, and the EQ and dynamics to be really versatile and consistent. I don’t have to think about building a chain, 90% of the time all the tools I need are there. Also, the EQ maps perfectly to the avid artist mix  encoders so I don’t need to look at the screen to EQ.

I’m a little skeptical that these other plug-ins would sound so much better as to really change things for me, but this discussion does have me thinking.

author: kalpipal
content: If you're talking heavy mix bus compression: if you can use an external side chain on your bus comp (and it isn't already being used), I'd create a sidechain bus and send every single relevant track/bus to it **pre-fader** at the track's approximate level (trying to get pre-fader send level to match post-fader so the sum total drives the comp the same way as it would in the mix.)

author: cian riordan
content: But if you're leaning into an analog emulation, then 0dBVU within that particular plugin is a good place to start.

author: cian riordan
content: If you're going into a compressor with a fixed threshold, then you're going to have to drive the input hotter to see GR. If it has a variable threshhold, then it wont really matter given there's likely a makeup gain stage.

author: cian riordan
content: If you're going into a Tape emulation or a saturation plugin, then you probably want to go a lot lower than 0dBFS unless you really want to distort your mix.

author: N
content:
I understand the perspective of (lufs don’t matter) however I want some consistency amongst my songs AND to be sufficiently loud compared to others.

I am competent of achieving very loud mixes however the introduction of artifacts bothers me. Usually I’m low passing with ISOL8 to listen for limiting/clipping clicks. These artifacts are unable to be heard unless I have a low pass filter active but I theorize that they, along with the extreme compression subconsciously degrade the listening experience by discretely assaulting your ears to the point of needing to take a break from listening. 

My music can be related sonically to clara la sans “another night” give or take more or less busy. (Keep in mind her stuff is cranked to the point of audible artifacts sitting around -7ish lufs integrated across the chorus).

I arrange the mix well and leave 1db of headroom for summing on individual instruments whilst they are loud enough for my target of -10 LUFi across the chorus, meaning my mix is actually 1db louder than -10 with space to sum on the pre master bus. Leaving headroom means I can introduce less artifacts at the cost of having to squeeze the dynamic range of individual instruments more than otherwise.

My issue is that If I want to aim for let’s say -8LUFSi across the chorus in a relatively clean way with minimal artifacts, I’m forced to squeeze the mix to -7.

I’d love to hear y’all thoughts on whether or not technically inaudible artifacts/distortion matter and whether or not it’s really worth for me to squeeze my mix 2db more in the name of competitive loudness?

Ps. Please bear with me as I am trying to figure this all out solo. Feel free to criticize my approach.

author: cian riordan
content: To answer your question, yes, audible artifacts matter and if they’re a result of you slamming a limiter or a clipper, then you’d be good to turn it down.

my premaster and master chains only have clippers or limiters shaving peaks. i try to do everything on individual instruments.

but i agree
